Sir,

I beg to advise you that the contract for the proposed new Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, Sask., has been awarded today to Mr. R. H. Wyatt of Winnipeg, at his tendered price of $25,619.00. He has been instructed before proceeding with the work to consult with Rev. Bishop Charlebois, Mr. Alwood of the Dominion Water Power Branch and yourself with reference to the location. I have written to Bishop Charlebois and Mr. Alwood and asked them to cooperate with you in selecting a suitable site for this building.

I will advise you in the near future the name of the party who will act as Inspector of Construction on this work.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed in this letter you will find four tenders for lighting Plant equipment for four reserves we understand are needing this class of equipment this season, namely:

- Morley, Alberta.
- Sturgeon Landing, Sask.
- Onion Lake, Sask.

Attention- Mr. Gurney Orr,

We beg to tender on lighting equipment for Sturgeon Landing Reserve, Sask.

To Supply a 6K.W Size "LISTER-BRUSTON" Patent Automatic ELECTRIC LIGHTING Plant of 6 K.W. Capacity at 110 Volts consisting of:

ENGINE:— A "Lister" & Cylinder 12 B.H.P. Vertical Water Cooled enclosed type Petrol Engine, running at 550 r.p.m. on full load, fitted with High Tension Magneto Ignition, Automatic Pump Fed Lubrication, Centrifugal Governor and specially designed for running long periods without attention. The engine is complete with water and fuel tanks, and connections, necessary spanners and a few spare parts.

DYNAMO:— An open protected type shunt wound Dynamo, having an output of 55 amperes at 110 volts, and coupled to the engine by means of flexible leather coupling.

BASE:— The above are mounted on cast iron base which forms foundation of Plant.

SWITCHBOARD:— An enamelled slate switchboard carrying voltmeter, 2 ammeters, patent relay and circuit breaker for automatic operation, and the necessary fuses and terminals.

OUTPUT:— This plant would be capable of carrying a load of 150 lamps of 40 Watts each, all on together. Also the necessary leather belting and pulleys to connect on Laundry Drive shaft.

BATTERY:— A Battery of 54 cells of 36 ampere hour capacity at the 30 hour rate, contained in glass jars, and complete with connecting strips, insulators, separators, connectors, etc. This Battery is the open type B.T. two plate Exide Manchester Chloride.

ACID:— Necessary concentrated acid for the above battery.

PRICE:— $3,990.00 completely installed at Sturgeon Landing Reserve ready to couple to building distribution.

Dear Sir,

We understand that the Dominion Government intend building an Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, and we write to say that we should be glad to have an opportunity of tendering for the Laundry Machinery.

We handle the machinery manufactured by Messrs D. & J. Tullis of Glasgow, and we can compete very favourably with all other makes on the market on this side of the Atlantic, besides giving you a very much more substantial make of machinery.

Ottawa, June 10, 1925.

Sir,

As advised by telegram of yesterday you have been appointed Inspector of Construction for the new Sturgeon Landing Indian Residential School, and you will be expected to devote all of your time to this work. You will be paid at the same rate as for your work at the Duck Lake School. The contract for the portion of the building which it is proposed to erect has been awarded to Mr. R. N. Wyatt of Winnipeg at his tendered price of $25,519, and it will be your duty to see that this building is erected in accordance with the plans and specifications, and also to issue progress certificates for payment on the contract, the procedure for which you are already familiar with.

I would particularly draw your attention to the fact that under no circumstances is any extra work to be authorized in connection with this contract that will add to the cost of the building, without first submitting an estimate of the cost to the Department and obtaining authority in writing.

For all information with reference to the site of the proposed building you are to communicate with Indian Agent Waddy at Le Pas, Man.

I am sending you, under separate cover blue print copies of the plans and specifications, tender forms and diary sheets, also certificate forms.

The voucher for your salary should be signed by Indian Agent Waddy, and forwarded to the Department attached to the diary sheets.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Nelson,
Aust., Deputy and Secretary.

Premier Laundry Machinery Co.,
721 Metropolitan Bldg.,
Vancouver, B.C.
I wish to advise the Department that, no matter which site is chosen, it will be necessary to expend money to clear the timber. I asked local men the cost of doing this work and their figures are all the way from $25.00 to $50.00 per acre. I have no idea of how much should be cleared, but would judge that at least 20 acres should be done to make the place fairly fire-proof, though this would not make it altogether safe as the forest is heavy all round this district. It might be well to allow the contractor to do the work on percentage basis, no local man made an offer, but there are one or two who would do it if given the chance. It could also be done by day labour under the inspector who goes in to superintend the construction of the building.

Dear Sir:

We have yours of the 23rd inst., and note contents. In answer to same will say:

Re page 3, paragraph 2, for first certificate. We sent you a list as we have sent to all architects that we have worked for, and it should be sufficient for you to issue a certificate on. If you thought the amount was too much it would have been easy enough for you to have sent part of it and asked for something different for the balance. However, I think what I have sent you will be sufficient for the department, as it would be up to you to check the amount of materials and put your own valuation on them, and see if this corresponds with the amounts asked for. If they didn't, then it would be in order for you to cut them down.

I might say that it takes two weeks from the time we send you a letter until we get a reply, and that if we do not get a certificate by return mail we will take this matter up direct with the Department.

Re doors:- While specifications call for 3 panel doors, 1/2" thick, we took the liberty of changing them to stock doors, as 3 panel doors are stock doors in the East, and the specifications being written in the East, they would naturally follow stock specifications, because I understand the Department's requirements are, that they don't purpose going into special work for Indian schools. All doors sent, except 4, which are 2-6-6-6 are 1/2". These 4 are 1 3/8", and not 1 1/8", as you mention. These are for closet doors and are always used for this class of work.

Re Windows:- Windows will be painted before being placed in the frames, as specified.

Re base & Casings:- The specification calls for moulded bases and casings. If you will look at cross section on the plan you will find that we have sent base exactly as is shown there, which is a moulded base, within the meaning of standard millwork specifications. Any wood that is worked other than being absolutely square is called moulded, and to match this base we sent bull nose casing, but if the Department were to insist on having a back band for this casing, which is not nearly so sanitary, we would certainly send it.

Re specifications for flooring:- Specifications call for hardwood flooring to be bored, driven up tight and nailed. If you will wait until this flooring is laid or until we are laying it to voice a complaint. I think that you will find that there will be no need of complaint, as I think our men will lay it to your entire satisfaction.
Re specifications for beams:- Specifications for beams reads as follows "beams shall be of 8x10, formed in long lengths of 2" thick, by depth of beam". It doesn't say that pieces that it is formed of shall be of long lengths, but that the beams shall be formed the full length of what is required of 2" material. This we have sent you, and to make up the beams we have sent 2x10-16's, with less than a 10 ft bearing, will be ample.

Re Outside Studding:- All outside studding are full lengths, with the exception of the jog in the foundation, which will have short studs, with plates on top doubled, and then top studding the same length as the balance of the building, on top of this. This is standard construction, as we have always done it.

Re Ceiling over Boiler Room:- Specifications distinctly say that all joints for floor joists will be 2x10. Cannot see how you can read 2x6 sideways for a solid floor. We have sent these joists for this job and they are on the ground, and if we had to re-order it would cost a lot of money; as this place is situated, as you are aware, a long ways from lumber yards. This we certainly did not figure on, and would expect an extra for the work if it were changed.

Re steps and platform in basement:- Page 21, paragraph 17 says, "build outside and inside steps and platforms indicated on plan of concrete, etc." Indicated means 'marked'. There are no steps marked. Page 29, paragraph 23, specifically mentions steps to chapel of wood. Page 33, paragraph 40, calls for stairs to be constructed where shown of wood. It would not look good construction to me to have reinforced concrete stairs and platform running up between frame walls, and would not take it as such. The stairs that we figure should go in concrete are those from the boiler room to hall, to engineers quarters, and machinery room. These are part of the floor, which are concrete and which will go in in concrete. The mill men in estimating this job also estimated this would go in in wood, as they read the specifications, and sent them that way. We are sorry that you interpret these any other way, as I am afraid your ruling is not correct.

Re certificate of radiation of boiler:- This we have mailed to you at your request.

I trust that the above explanations will meet with your approval. If not, I would ask you to kindly get the architect, Mr. Orr's interpretation, and let me have it.

Trusting that we will hear from you, with certificate enclosed by return of mail, we remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Your foreman on the works of the construction of Guy Indian School at this point has given me your statement of material delivered to date but I regret to say that I cannot accept same before the following are adjusted and before the conditions set forth on page 3, paragraph 2 of specifications (Before teh 1st certificate etc) are realized.

2o-The windows should have been painted before being sent but it is understood that they will have to be painted before being placed in frames.

3o-The bases and casings; the specifications call for moulded bases ans casings but as just plain bull nose ones were received I cannot accept them.

4o-According to specifications flooring should be bored. I wish to have the flooring nailed at about 3" from the end and not 7 or 8 inches. Therefore kindly see that this matter is attended to.

5o-Specifications mention that beams must be made up of long pieces. As I do not see any here I must say that I will not accept short pieces or beams made up in two pieces. For your information I may tell you that long pieces as desired can be had in The Pas.

6o-Outside studing; the latter 2x6 should be full length. I do not see them on the grounds. Please order them.

7o-Ceiling over boiler room: Plan shows 2x6 edgeways solid floor. Kindly see that this is complied with.

Dear Sir:

We have yours of the 23rd inst., and note contents. In answer to same will say:

Re page 3, paragraph 2, for first certificate. We sent you a list as we have sent to all architects that we have worked for, and it should be sufficient for you to issue a certificate on. If you thought the amount was too much it would have been easy enough for you to have sent part of it and asked for something different for the balance. However, I think what I have sent you will be sufficient for the department, as it would be up to you to check the amount of materials and put your own valuation on them, and see if this corresponds with the amounts asked for. If they didn't, then it would be in order for you to cut them down.

I might say that it takes two weeks from the time we send you a letter until we get a reply, and that if we do not get a certificate by return mail we will take this matter up direct with the Department.

Re doors:- While specifications call for 3 panel doors 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" thick, we took the liberty of changing them to stock doors, as 3 panel doors are stock doors in the East, and the specifications being written in the West, they would naturally follow stock specifications being written because I understand the Departments requirements are that they don't purpose going into special stock for Indian Schools. All doors sent, except 4, which are 2-6-6-6 are 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)". These 4 are 1 3/8, and not 1 1/8, as you mention. These are for closet doors and are always used for this class of work.

Re windows:- Windows will be painted before being placed in the frames, as specified.

Re base and casings:- The specification calls for moulded bases and casings. If you will look at cross section on the plan you will find that we have sent base exactly as is shown there, which is a moulded base, within the meaning of standard millwork specifications. Any wood that is worked other than being absolutely square is called moulded, and to match this base we sent bull nose casing, but if the department were to insist on having a back band for this casing, which is not nearly so sanitary, we would certainly send it.

Re specifications for flooring:- Specifications call for hardwood flooring to be bored, driven up tight and nailed. If you will wait until this flooring is laid or until we are laying it to voice a complaint I think that you will find that there will be no need of complaint, as I think our men will lay it to your entire satisfaction.

Re specifications for beams:- Specifications for beams reads as follows "beams shall be of 8x10, formed in long lengths of 2" thick, by depth of beam". It doesn't say that pieces that it is formed of shall be of long lengths, but that the beams shall be formed the full length of what is required of 2" material. This we have sent you, and to make up the beams we have sent 2x10-16's, with less than a 10 ft. bearing will be ample.

Re Outside studding:- All outside studding are full lengths, with the exception of the jog in the foundation, which will have short studs, with plates on top doubled, and then your studding the same length as the balance of the building, on top of this. This is standard construction as we have always done it.

Re Ceiling over Boiler Room:- Specifications distinctly say that all joists for floor joists will be 2x10. Cannot see how you can read 2x6 sideways for a solid floor. We have sent these joists for this job and they are on the ground, and if we had to re-order it would cost a lot of money, as this place is situated as you are aware, a long ways from lumber yards. This we certainly did not figure on, and would expect an extra for the work if it were changed.

Re steps and platform in basement:- Page 21, paragraph 17 says "build outside and inside steps and platforms indicated on plan of concrete, etc." Indicated means 'marked'. There are no steps marked. Page 29, paragraph 23, specifically mentions steps to chapel of wood. Page 33, paragraph 40, calls for stairs to be constructed where shown of wood. It would not look good construction to me to have reinforced concrete stairs and platform running up between frame walls, and would not take it as such. The stairs that we figure should go in in concrete are those from the boiler room to hall, the engineers quarters, and machinery room, these are part of the floor, which are concrete and which will go in in concrete. The millwrights in estimating this job also estimated this would go in in wood, as they read the specifications, and sent them that way. We are sorry that you interpret these any other way, as I am afraid your ruling is not correct.

Re certificate of radiation of boiler:- This we have mailed to you at your request.

I trust that the above explanations will meet with your approval. If not, I would ask you to kindly get the architect, Mr. Orr's interpretation, and let me have it.

Trusting that we will hear from you, with certificate enclosed by return of mail, we remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Your foreman on the works of the construction of Guy Indian School at this point has given me your statement of material delivered to date but I regret to say that I cannot accept same before the following are adjusted and before the conditions set forth on page 3, paragraph 3 of specifications (Before teh 1st certificate etc) are realized.

1o-The doors are not as specified. Instead of 1½" three panel doors all those received are with five panels and some only 1". I therefore refuse those doors.

2o-The windows should have been painted before being sent but it is understood that they will have to be painted before being placed in frames.

3o-The bases and casings; the specifications call for moulded bases ans casings but as just plain bull nose ones were received I cannot accept them.

4o-According to specifications flooring should be bored. I wish to have the flooring nailed at about 3" from the end and not 7 or 8 inches. Therefore kindly see that this matter is attended to.

5o-Specifications mention that beams must be made up of long pieces. As I do not see any here I must say that I will not accept short pieces or beams made up in two pieces. For your information I may tell you that long pieces as desired can be had in The Pas.

7o-Outside studing; the latter 2x6 should be full length. I do not see them on the grounds. Please order them.

7o-Sealing over boiler room: Plan shows 2x6 edgeways solid floor. Kindly see that this is complied with.
So—Steps and platform in basement.

By what is sent it looks as if those were to be made in wood but specifications distinctly call for concrete steps and platforms and I insist upon this point.

9c—Certificate of radiation of boilers from the manufacture must be sent to me as soon as possible in order to enable me to accept said boilers.

You will note by the above remarks that I do not ask anything outside of what is called for in the specifications and plans but I insist upon having it.

Another point which I wish to call to your attention is the fact that your statement of material delivered is incomplete and not enough detailed. By the experience I have in connection with such contracts I am positive that the Department of Indian Affairs would certainly not accept your statement and figures as set forth in your last communication.

I am sending a copy of this letter to the Architect of the Indian Department at Ottawa and another to Commissioner Graham, Indian Department at Regina.

I hope that you will give immediate attention to the above and adjust whatever is found deficient.

Yours truly,

There is an argument in regard to a stairway leading up between the laundry and the storeroom. The Department can judge which is the correct interpretation, either stairway or steps. There are dozens of little objections not noted here that were drawn to my attention by the Inspector.

Sir,

In reference to various telegrams regarding Inspector Taillon at Guy Indian Residential School. I beg to report that I was at Surgeon Landing on the 16th inst., and went over the building in company with Mr. Taillon and Mr. Alyea, the Foreman for Mr. Wyatt.

Mr. Taillon pointed out that the walls are not thirteen inches in thickness. Some of these walls are more than thirteen inches, some slightly less than thirteen inches, and the foreman explained that in running the concrete he allows for the form expanding when the concrete is being poured, and pressure comes on it. In some places the pressure did not expand the forms to full thirteen inches. The wall itself is constructed in first class shape.

The joists and sills do not come flush at every angle of the floor and walls. There is a small space between some of the joists and sills. Mr. Taillon states that this is not according to specifications; that they should be exactly flush, and tight, in every instance.

The walls of the first floor are sheeted in, and the building is well under way. The mill work, hardware, sheet metal, plumbing, and heating equipment, brick etc. is on the ground.

The Inspector objects to some of the piping being second hand, but the Contractor states that this second hand pipe is being filled with cement and used as some sort of a stand under the pipes, but no second hand pipe is really on hand for general use.

The Inspector also objects to the shed, which is used to house the mill work. Although this shed is water-proof from the top, he states that the rain can drift in through the sides into the mill work. Up to the present little damage seems to have been done from this cause but no doubt Mr. Taillon was right to object to the shape of the building.

DOMINION WATER POWER AND RECLAMATION SERVICE
Winnipeg, Man.

August 18th, 1925.

Sir,

Herewith are two copies of Mr. Craig's report providing for a Water Supply, Power and Lighting and Sewerage System for the Guy Indian School Sturgeon Landing, Saskatchewan. As we have had no reply to the questions asked in our letter of July 22nd we have assumed that the requirements of these services will be for an institution of 100 inmates and with a limited power supply and fire protection.

The investigation of the Sturgeonweir river showed quite conclusively that a water power development for the requirements of the Guy Indian School would be too costly and for that reason Mr. Craig has provided for moderately priced but reliable oil engines, which I feel are suitably adapted for the requirements of the institution. In selecting suitable machinery Mr. Craig received actual prices for all equipment f.o.b. Winnipeg, and in going into this matter he found that while a number of firms could supply various machines, fittings, equipment, etc., the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse company are prepared to supply a complete installation. In my opinion it would appear advisable when calling for tenders for the above machinery and installation that tenders should be called for from firms who can and will supply and install the machinery, equipment, etc. In addition to facilitating the work it places the responsibility for the completion and successful operation of the entire plant upon one firm.

With respect to the installation of the sewerage system and the intake pipe for the water supply system I am of the opinion that a price for this work should be received from R.M. Watt, the present contractor of the school building. I feel sure that he would be prepared to quote a reasonable price for this work, or that he could do the work on a cost plus basis, naming an approximate completed job. I would further point out that it is absolutely necessary, if the Department of Indian Affairs decide to proceed with this work, that the equipment which may be decided upon should be purchased immediately, and the work be started with the least possible delay.

The plans of the sewerage and water system accompanying the report are in sufficient detail to permit the contractor to proceed with this work immediately. With respect to the purchasing of the engines, generators, pump, tank, shafting, pulleys, belts, etc., if the Department are satisfied with the machinery installation as outlined in Mr. Craig's report, specifications for these machines can be forwarded immediately.

Your obedient servant,

J.T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director, Water Power & Reclamation,
Sgd... G.H. Attwood,
Department of the Interior,
District Chief Engineer.
Ottawa, Ontario.
Sir,

On April 9th last you wrote asking that we have a report prepared as to the feasibility of erecting a small hydro electric power plant and make recommendations as to water supply and sewage disposal for an Indian residential school at Sturgeon Landing (your file number 132-7-15). I now beg to enclose copy of a letter from our District Chief Engineer at Winnipeg, Mr. G.H. Attwood, together with a copy of a report covering the ground outlined in your letter of April 9th.

You will note from Mr. Attwood's letter that a water-power development would be too costly and that the engineer has therefore provided for a moderately priced but reliable oil engine installation. You will also note his various recommendations as to the manner in which the work might be carried out.

Mr. Attwood states that if your Department decides to proceed with this work the equipment which may be decided upon should be purchased immediately and the work started with the least possible delay.

Your obedient servant,

WINNIPEG August 25th, 1925.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

-Attention Mr. O'Keeffe,
Re Guy Residential School.

I would like to report to you after visiting this building under construction last week as to how I found things.

It seems that Mr. Alyea, our foreman, and the Inspector Mr. Taillon, could not get along. This is partly due to the fact that the place is so isolated, and weather conditions very bad (in fact, it rained nearly every night in July and quite a number of days) together with mosquitoes, of which I believe they have never known them to be worse, (in fact the Indians that we had engaged could scarcely stand them). Then the heat, bull dogs, which attacked the horses and sand flies, together with Mr. Taillon bothering the man on the other hand, it got him nearly bushed. However, he seems to be doing a very good job, and in speaking with Mr. Taillon I found him a very nice old gentleman who would possibly want to put something over you if he thought he could get away with it, but after discussing the building in general with him and he found out that I knew just about as much about the job as he did, he became very amicable, in fact, I don't think I would have any trouble in the world getting along with him myself.

Mr. Taillon states that he has written the Department asking for advice on how he was to interpret the specifications, and that he had received no reply. I think this possibly had something to do with his retiring. There were several matters of contention which he took up with me, a copy of my letter to him was mailed to the Department. No doubt you will be able to see it.

Would like to have your orders on this given to your new Inspector, and a copy of same sent to me. It must be remembered that it takes two weeks from the time that I get a letter from our foreman on the job until we can get a reply back to him, and in the meantime something has got to be done to push the job along. I think it would be necessary for you to instruct your Inspector to be able to decide these things at the moment.

There is the matter of electric lighting fixtures, in which the amount of $175.00 has been allotted. Would be pleased to have your recommendations as to the class of fixtures to be installed, as the electrician is now on the job and we want to send them as quickly as possible.

Another matter that we haven't yet taken up with the Inspector is as to how you purpose having the return pipes to the boiler placed under the floor. It says in the specifications "as shown", but
we figured nothing for this, as there was nothing shown. Kindly let us know what you would have done in this case.

Would be pleased to receive a reply from you at your earliest convenience, as we expect to be plastering this job the week after next and would like to have the floor put in before we start the plastering.

I think it would be better if you would allow me to write you instead of to the Inspector in charge, a copy of which could be sent to him, as it would help matters a great deal on account of the slowness of the mails in that direction.

Trusting to hear from you, I remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

RNW/EB.
Ottawa, Aug. 28, 1925.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 18th instant with reference to the work at the Guy Indian Residential School, I beg to say that the Department has issued a certificate (No. 1) in favour of the contractor for $3,000, and a cheque for this amount has wired him yesterday.

I am enclosing herewith a copy of the certificate which I would ask you to please forward to the building inspector.

With regard to your comments on the building I would say that it would appear that the concrete walls should be satisfactory. Regarding the stair leading up between the laundry and store room, it was the intention that these be built of wood, in fact steps which come between concrete walls should be built of concrete and those between plastered walls on frame work of wood.

It is hoped that Mr. Grant, the newly appointed Inspector of Construction, will be able to arrange all matters satisfactorily with the contractor.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 25th instant with reference to the Guy Indian Residential School, I have noted your remarks with regard to the difficulties experienced in the carrying out of this work on account of local conditions. I addressed a letter yesterday to Indian Agent Waddy, advising him that the Department had issued a certificate for $6,000 as a payment on your contract. I also advised him that from his report it would appear that the concrete walls would be satisfactory, and that the stairs leading up between the laundry and store room should be built of wood, and that steps which come between concrete walls should be built of concrete and those between plastered walls on frame work of wood.

With reference to the electric lighting fixtures, I am today writing to Mr. Bunn to select these fixtures, and I would ask you to please get in touch with him.

With regard to the return heating pipes under the floor, these may be covered up and the floor finished in the regular way. Regarding the other items in connection with the building which came up between your former and Mr. Taillon, these will have to be left to Mr. Grant, the new Inspector, and I think he will be able to make satisfactory arrangements.

Your obedient servant,

Sir;

In reference to the Guy Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, I would be obliged if the Department will advise me if it is the intention to have this place heated this coming winter. In my opinion it will be necessary to keep the frost from getting in and heaving the foundations.

In case it is decided to heat the place it would be well to have wood cut immediately and it could be done under the supervision of Inspector of Construction Roderick Grant.

I have had the timber on the 20 acres saved for wood, but it is green poplar. We could use it if a similar quantity of dry wood was used in the furnaces at the same time.

Any instructions thought necessary in this matter will be appreciated, we have not much time to think it over as the winter will soon be coming in this district.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Re - Construction work on the above School. I would be pleased to have a decision with reference to the Construction of the floor over water room. When I checked up the work done here I found that the Contractor constructed the floor the same as the floors throughout the main part of the building now under Construction with 2" x 10" Joists. I will refer you to the plans sheet No. 2 Cross section A-A shown the floor to be Constructed of 2" x 6" spiked together. When I asked the foreman about the change from the plans he told me that was what they called for. He also referred me to the Specification of Carpentry plan page 28 clause 14 dealing with Joists according to the Specification all Ceilings on the ground floor excepting water room to be finished with Metal Ceiling according to the foreman interpretation of the ceiling of water room will have open joists. In the plumbing and drainage inside the building the water closet completed except for the line from the bath room which they are working upon now. There is no plans here showing disposal of the sewage outside the building. The same applies to the water service, if the bathers are to be used this winter it will be necessary that the installation take place at once if not we will not be able to get a test on the heating system before the steam fitter go away as I have been here a little over two weeks. I cannot find any information dealing with the part of the work, I do not know what arrangement had
made previous to my coming here there is no record left here for me to go by regarding the degree of surveying plans prepared for the new building we would like to have a copy here.

Chimney:

Plan of heating layout sheet No. 6 shows to figure that the chimney for boiler base flue 31" x 31" x 6' high. The chimney head 31" x 31" x 6' high. This would bring the top of the Capping on chimney 17' above the ridge of the present main roof. The height of the domestic chimney is 52' high.

Please advise if I am right. I have not seen the plans for the future extension and do not know the height of the highest part of the water tower.

Plan sheet No. 3 shows an opening in wall between Scullery and the future building to be boarded up the same as the other three openings. If we had the height of this opening it could be framed there at no height given at present the Contracting Council this wall on the outside with 10% of shingles. The work will take the Contractor about five weeks. Complete the plaster work is not started yet the bricks are set and the steam pipes are on the heating plant. The plumber is well advanced with the drainage under the building. The Concrete floor has been put in when practical to work.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 12th instant with reference to the work on the new Guy Indian Residential School, I beg to give you the following information on the different points mentioned in your letter:

1. Boiler Room Ceiling.
   The specifications call for boiler room ceiling to be built of 3 x 10 joists similar to other portions of the building and no extra covering of any kind is specified for this ceiling. If you can make satisfactory arrangements as to price with the contractors you may arrange to have the ceiling covered with sheets of galvanized iron.

2. It is not the intention to install this year the water supply or sewage disposal systems, as there are no funds for this work, and they will be included in the plans and specifications when these are completed for the finished building. You may, therefore, make the most economical arrangements possible for temporary water supply for the building and temporary drainage.

3. The chimneys should be built to the height as shown on the elevations.

4. The opening shown between scallery and future building should be the width as shown on plan, and the bottom opening three feet from floor line, and top opening six feet from floor line.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Your letter of September 29th inst., to hand, replying to my letter of the 12th inst., with reference to certain part of the work on the contract.

I note that you advise that the joists over the boiler room should be 3" x 16" as per specifications. I admit that the specifications read 3" x 16" joists but the plans call for or show 2" x 6" laminated floor. As you have decided to cover the ceiling with galvanized iron it will be satisfactory as a fire prevention. I am getting a price from the contractor for this work. I am also getting a price direct on the material ourselves, and if required will do the work.

Regarding the heating plant, we are arranging to heat the building this winter with wood heaters. We are also going to make a test on the heating plant before the boilers and piping are covered.

Chimneys are built to the height above the present roof as shown on elevation.

The opening between scullery and future building is the width shown on plan. Height 5'-0" from finished floor to bottom of opening, 6' from finished floor to top of opening.

In regard to the present excavation for the future building it will be necessary to have this drained, otherwise the present building would be flooded in the Spring. I have asked the contractor to have this done before he completes his contract.

In regard to the outside drainage of sewage disposal the contractor has made a ditch 18 ft deep from the point where the cast iron soil pipe comes out of the building on the right side elevation, 15' north of the entrance to the basement. This ditch runs southeast for 190 ft, towards the riverbank. This work was started before I took over the inspectorship. There is no records showing that this work was included in the present contract. The foreman on the job says that the contractor instructed him to have this done and a record kept on the time.

I may state that we will drain the heating system after making the test through this drain. We will have some difficulty in getting a supply of water from the river, but will do the best we can.

I am, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

Inspector.

In reference to letter 132-7-15 of the 2nd inst regards appointment of Mr. E. Millette as fireman at Guy Indian Residential School, I beg to state that this man left The Pas on the last boat leaving for that point on the 13th inst.

The Captain of the steamboat just informed me that he just got to Cumberland, which is half way to Sturgeon Landing, and then ran into a snow storm which held him up. When the storm was over the lake had frozen over. He waited two days to see if the ice would move, and when he saw it had tightened up for the winter he unloaded all his passengers, and came back down the river.

Mr. Millette is marooned at Cumberland House until such time as dog teams can cross the lake to Sturgeon Landing, and in the meanwhile the Inspector of Construction, R. Grant is ice bound at the school in company with the contractor's foremen, his painters and carpenters, and may be there three weeks or a month more before travelling is safe.

When I put in the pay list for Mr. Millette at what date will I start his time, I think it should be allowed from the 14th at which time he would have started work if the elements had not interfered.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

Owing to the water in Cumberland Lake being frozen over we have had no mail service since the 8th, of Oct., the material required to finish the work came as far as Cumberland and owing to the boat been unable to come through to the landing it was taken back to the Pass.

With reference to the heating of the building during the present winter, it will be possible to use the boilers all winter as we have arranged to have the necessary supply of water when required.

During the month of Oct., we used one of the boilers to heat the building in place of heaters as it was the best way to dry out the building, at present we have the two boilers filled with water, by having one boiler filled and held in reserve they will have to refill them once during the winter from the river.

DOMINION WATER POWER BRANCH
Winnipeg, Manitoba,
November 27, 1925.

Sir,

This will acknowledge your letter of November 21st with reference to the request of the Departmental Engineer of the Department of Indian Affairs for additional elevations and contours on the general plan accompanying the report on the water supply and sewerage system for the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing.

Enclosed you will please find a general plan with further elevations shown. At the time Mr. Patterson made the survey of the school site the question of supplying the school from a storage tank was not taken into account and the elevations of the ground some distance back from the river were not secured. Mr. Patterson states, however, that there is very little rise in the land for a considerable distance from the river, and I consider that the slight increase in height that would be gained by locating the tank some distance back from the river, would not compensate for the additional expense of the piping.

I note that the Departmental Engineer desires me to mark what I consider is the most suitable location for a storage tank to take the place of the pneumatic pressure tank proposed in the report. With very little difference in the elevation of the ground in the vicinity of the school, the storage tank might be placed at any point that would be most suitable in connection with the required water mains.

The suggestion is made that, with the practically level ground surrounding the school, it might be more feasible to arrange to have the water tank placed either in the top storey or on top of the school. This is only a suggestion, and if realized, changes in the design of the school might be necessary to support the weight of the tank when filled with water.

Your obedient servant,

G. H. Attwood,
District Chief Engineer.

Per.... J.C.

The Director,

Dear Sir;-

RE GUY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL. STURGEON LANDING.

Regards my letter to you of the 31st October with a list of the work to be completed on the above school, I beg to report that since then all the material required to complete the work was delivered at the school and all the items on list were completed on the above date.

The work has been completed as per plans and specifications except for the following changes and omissions. 1. Brick chimney for boiler; the base of the chimney was carried up to a height of ten feet in concrete above the concrete footing, then finished in brick to the height given on plans. Concrete base was in place when I took over the work.

2. Opening in partition wall between machine room and laundry; plan shows opening to have doors the same as shown on outside double door on the rear wall to machine room; the partition was changed from the location shown on plan and moved seven feet into space allowed for laundry; opening has been finished with plain jamb and casing.

3. Cross on roof; the plan shows cross on roof, rear elevation. This has not been done as shown, the contractors foreman had no instructions to do this work as there was no mention of it in the specifications. If the Department does not have it done His Lordship Bishop Charlesbois informs me he will be pleased to contribute it himself.

4. Grading has been done on the rear elevation and right side elevation, there is approximately about 75 yards of earth to be graded on the left side.

5. The following were sub-contractors on the work. J.Davidson, Winnipeg, contractor on the plastering. I have to report that all the plaster, cement and keen cement work was finished as per specifications excepting the work done in the machine room, hallways and stairway and plaster work above the keen cement on the walls in the laundry which owing to difficulties with delay of material and delay by the carpenters not being prepared for the plaster the plasterers lost considerable time and wanted to get away to catch the last boat so they put the finishing coat on before the undercoat was properly dry as per the manufacturers specifications. They were over.
They were told, along with the contractors foreman, that these walls were not ready for the finish coat and if they put it on it was at their own risk as they were working away from the specifications. I have to report that this part of the work has shown up well under the circumstances.

Standard Plumbing and Heating Co., Winnipeg, were contractors on plumbing and heating. The heating plant has been installed as per specifications, with one omission from the plans, it has reference to installation of the radiator in the scullery, 27 sq ft of which was to be connected up and removed when future extension is to be made. We did not require the radiator so did not connect it up and give a finished job to the heating plant in this part. The heating plant has been in operation since the end of September and there is one boiler operating all the time and will be during the winter. The heating plant is giving first class satisfaction all radiators are working satisfactorily. The plumbing has been installed with all fixtures as per specifications, and all drains and connections as per sketch submitted showing the drainage layout.

Shumacher & Gray, Winnipeg put in the electric wiring. This is completed, according to specifications, fixtures hung and all switch and push plates in position. All wiring was finished except for boiler room, fuel room and stairway before I took charge.

With reference to the general construction of the building all work was done while I was in charge in accordance with the plans and specifications.

I would draw your attention to the finished floor laid in chapel. The flooring supplied in accordance to specifications #1 Maple. I beg to report that it is a poor grade of #1, it was badly matched, varying 1/16 inch in width and when #1 Maple is mentioned in specifications it should be #1 best grade as there are several grades of #1 Maple flooring on the market. It did not help the flooring being stored at the school site all summer during the wet season although it was under a roof. Kiln dried maple is very susceptible to moisture which it absorbs; while on the matter of finish flooring it is right that I should mention that the floor joists should all be sized before the rough floor is laid; in the present case the sizing of the floor joists did not help the laying of this grade of maple flooring. The flooring is 13/16" thick.

Regards interior doors, all the doors supplied were 1¾" thick of good quality fir 5 cross panels, except for the two doors at rear of platform in chapel which are 1¾" thick taking the place of three panel doors specified, the only difference is in the design.

All interior staining and varnishing has been completed, also all outside painting as per specifications.
The contractor has supplied and fitted all the window screens and screen doors as per specifications, all having been marked for their proper location and stored in the store room, all windows are fitted with storm sash with one sliding panel to each window.

The excavation for the future building has been done to the depth called for, but no excavation has been done for the footings. It was necessary to have a trench dug from the lowest point of the excavations to the river bank for drainage in the spring. Instructions have been left with the fireman to keep the drain open.

Covering of boilers and steam pipes and all fittings in piping covered as per specifications, also jacket heater for summer use covered. All return pipes and boiler front in boiler room painted. All bare risers, radiators and piping in building not covered painted as per specifications.

There is a piece of cement base not on wall, right side of hallway from future building entrance. I gave instructions at the time the plasterers were doing the plaster work not to put it in as they had no time, the length of this piece of base is only 12 feet and they were not in position to do it at the time to my satisfaction.

In handing over the building to the fireman instructions were left with him as to the temperature required during the winter in the building. The building is now thoroughly dried out and there is no sign of dampness. We are heating the building by using one of the boilers and will be able to do so all winter, this will allow the fireman every opportunity to regulate the heat as best required.

When there was no possible means of heating the building before the boilers were in use and no water service I asked Mr. Waddy to ship me three heaters and stove pipe for emergency. After getting word from Ottawa that there would be no water service this year and advising me to make the best arrangements possible to heat the building and as I have already reported to the Department the heating of the building with the boilers was preferrable to heating by stoves I left the stoves which are not being used in the care of the fireman.

Considering the circumstances and difficulties under which the construction of this building was put up I would say that we got a good job and value received.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Inspector of Construction.
DEAR SIR:-

RE GUY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

I would further add to my report to you of the 23rd of November on the completion of the work on the contract of the erection of the above new school, that the prospects of finding suitable sand and gravel at sturgeon landing should be well considered by the contractors tendering on the work of the proposed extension to the present building next year.

There is plenty of good gravel to be had at the Pas suitable for the work that would cost $5.00 per c. yard landed at the school site this price for gravel would run up the cost of the concrete work. There is suitable gravel to be found at the landing providing time is taken to locate the best to comply with the specifications by the contractor and approved of by the inspector in charge before delivered on the job if this is done there should be no trouble about the gravel after delivered on the job, they will have to figure on hauling sand and gravel anywhere from 3 to 10 miles return trip. I was told that the contractor on the present building hauled 6 loads per day with one team hauling one yard and a quarter to a load this gravel was not up to all the requirements in the specifications, the gravel used in the concrete floors in the basement was of a better grade.

I would also recommend that the contractor have all cement lime and plaster tested out before it leaves the yards, if does not come direct from the cement plant, if this is done it will prevent the use of inferior material on the work, sometimes the yards is carrying old stock which has deteriorated unknown to the management and they ship the material to some job as good stock, if this test is made the trouble with bad material will be eliminated.

I would also recommend that the plans for the future extension provide for eavestroughing the same should apply to the building now completed as the rain water from roofs affect the foundation walls through time although they received a heavy coat of waterproofing on the outside.

Since I made out my last report a patch of plaster 2ft.x 4ft., sealed in the pantry it has being pointed out to the contractor it is not much only the putty coat that sealed, an allowance should be made by him to have this repaired by the plasters on the work next year.

I would also recommend that if the proposed work go on next year that arrangements be made for an early start on the work so that the contractor will have a chance to finish in time before the freeze up takes place, this year the work was not finished before the freeze up came and the contractor and his men were placed at a disadvantage to get out, one man had his feet frozen and another a bone broken in his foot on the ice, the contractor reports that they will both be laid up for two months, I trust you will take my recommendations as given with the best intentions,

yours truly

Inspector

Dear Sir:

We are in receipt of your letter dated November 12th re cheque, and might say that when we make out cheques we make them out from time sheets, as made out by our foreman, and these are supposed to be O.K'd by the workman. Mr. Alyea, our foreman, claims that you are not a first class painter by any means and we paid you as a second class painter.

We took the matter up with Mr. Weber as to what he thought the wages were in your town for that class of man, and this is the amount that we paid you.

I cannot understand how you arrive at your statements, as we never asked Mr. Lovell to go up except through Mr. Weber, whom I wired to see if he could get a couple of painters to go up. It would be much better if you could get in touch with Mr. Weber and ask him if he quoted any wages to Mr. Lovell. I want you to understand that we pay a rate of wages in keeping with a man's ability, but understand too that if a man does not prove to be first class and we agree beforehand to pay him a certain wage we will certainly pay him that. In this case I have got to be informed as to what rate you were promised. Upon receipt of this information I will take the matter up again.

I am sorry that any adjustment like this has to be made, as I am not in the habit of having any disputes with anybody regarding wages.

I am enclosing a copy of this letter to Mr. Wady, and will ask him for his opinion.

Yours truly,

Sir:

MEMORANDUM Mr. Scott.

Plans and specifications are now ready for the installation of a sewage disposal and water supply system for the Guy Indian Residential School, now in course of erection at Sturgeon Landing, Sask. The sewerage system consist principally in the construction of a septic tank and two separate sewer lines from the building to the tank, the outlet sewer from the tank to discharge directly into the Sturgeon Lake. The estimated cost of this work will amount to $1,800.

The water work system as projected will comprise an eighty gallon per minute typhoon pump, operated by an eight H. P. gasoline or oil engine, all of which can be installed in the basement in a room specially provided for same. The water will be conducted from the lake into an intake well by gravity, from where it will be pumped into an elevated water tank, which will be embodied in the new addition.

The reason for placing the tank above the building is due to the fact that the school grounds are practically level and a saving will be made in both the cost of construction and the maintenance.

The estimated cost of the water works, including the pipe line, which will be about 700 feet long, will amount to $3,000. exclusive of the cost of the tank, the plans for which are under preparation.

Upon consulting with Mr. Orr it was found advisable that the capacity of the engine specified for the water work system be such as to equally operate the electric generator, which will be required for this building. I have therefore prepared a specification for the electric generating plant in order that the machinery may be adjusted in co-ordination with that of the water supply. It will consist of a five K. W., D. C., 110 volt generator, a switch board complete with ammeter, voltmeter, fuses, switches, etc. and a 200 ampere hour storage battery.

REPORT ON
WATER SUPPLY, ELECTRIC LIGHT AND POWER INSTALLATION,
AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM
FOR
GUY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL,
STURGEON LANDING, SASKATCHEWAN.

Winnipeg, Manitoba,
August, 1925.

by John Craig.
INTRODUCTORY.

The Gay Indian Residential School now under construction by the Department of Indian Affairs, is located at Sturgeon Landing on the right bank of the Sturgeon river some 2,000 feet above Namew lake, into which it empties. This report outlines a water supply, electric light and power installation, and sewerage system for the school, together with the estimated cost thereof. It is proposed to install both plants in the machinery room shown in the plans of the school.

WATER SUPPLY AND POWER.

GENERAL.

An investigation was made of the feasibility of developing hydro power for the school from the Sturgeon river. The investigation showed however that the cost would be excessive for the small amount of power required and it was decided to use two oil engines for the necessary power.

The water supply system is designed to fully supply the domestic demand for over 100 inmates and give a limited fire protection. The electric lighting and power plant comprises a 7½ k.w. and a 5½ k.w. generator, driven by a 10 h.p. and 6 h.p. oil engine respectively, which should amply take care of the light and power demands of the institution.

As shown on the General Layout Plan No. 1, it is proposed to take the water from the river some 700 feet north of the school, a four-inch intake pipe running from the river to the school. As this is some distance above the sewer outlet, with rapids between the sewer outlet and the water intake, there should be no danger of the water supply being polluted.
The proposed plant calls for two oil engines, a 10 h.p. and a 6 h.p. By means of a line shaft either engine can be used for driving the pump or the electric generators. With this duplicate power there should be no interruption to either the water or electrical service.

WATER SUPPLY.

Intake.

As shown on General Layout Plan No. 1, it is proposed to take the water from the river about 700 feet north of the rear end of the school through a four inch wrought iron pipe. This location was decided on in order to avoid the necessity of having to go far out into the river to avoid freezing. At the location shown on the plan for the point of intake, the current is fairly swift near the shore and at the present level the water is ten feet deep a short distance out. No trouble should therefore be experienced from freezing during the winter. Another reason for choosing this location was the advisability of going a certain distance above the sewer outlet. As between this point and the sewer outlet there is a fairly swift rapids, no danger from pollution should be incurred. A ridge of rock about 150 feet wide, three feet below the ground will make part of the excavation for the intake line expensive, as it will be necessary to have at least five feet of covering over it to ensure against frost.

Pumping Plant.

The proposed pump will be of the plunger type similar to the Fairbanks-Morse "Typhoon Pumps" capable of pumping 90 g.p.m. against 60 pounds pressure with either an independent air compressor or with the compressor attached to the pump. The plunger type of pump is chosen on account of the long suction pipe. As shown on the Machinery Layout Plan No. 2
the pump will be driven from a line shaft. Two sources of power will be available, either from a 10 h.p. or a 6 h.p. oil engine. This should ensure continuous service. From a three-inch discharge pipe the water goes to a 12" x 4" pneumatic pressure tank and from there to the school water mains. Though the proposed pumping plant will more than supply the domestic requirements, only a limited amount of fire protection will be given. It is considered, however, that for any ordinary outbreak of fire the supply should be sufficient.

ELECTRIC LIGHTING AND POWER.

The Say Indian school is remotely situated from rail and water transportation during the winter months and in order to provide continuous service it is most advisable to install two power units. In the following layout two units are proposed, the larger unit being sufficient to meet most of the power requirements of the institution as finally completed. In case of breakdown or engine trouble either power unit would provide light and water service.

The electric lighting and power plant will consist of a 7½ k.w. and a 3½ k.w. D.C. generator. As shown on Machinery Layout Plan No. 2 the 7½ k.w. generator will be driven from the line shaft by the 10 h.p. oil engine already mentioned, or in case of its breakdown by the 6 h.p. oil engine. The 3½ k.w. generator will ordinarily be direct belt driven by the 6 h.p. oil engine, but in case of this engine failing it may be driven from the line shaft from the 10 h.p. engine. By this means practically continuous operation will be secured.
The 3½ k.w. generator should supply most of the electric power for lighting, while the larger generator may be used either for power or lighting requirements.

A one panel switchboard with voltmeter, ammeter and necessary switches is provided as shown on Machinery Layout Plan No. 2.

Laundry Room Service.

As shown on the Machinery Layout Plan No. 2, the line shaft is carried through to the laundry and the necessary power can be taken either from the 10 h.p. or 6 h.p. oil engine.

SEWERAGE SYSTEM.

GENERAL.

As the Guy Indian Residential School will have about 100 inmates the emptying of raw sewerage into the river was not considered advisable, and the following is a report on the proposed sewerage system that is considered would answer the requirements. Plans and profiles, together with estimates of the cost accompany this report. The elevations given on the plans and profiles are sea level, Topographic Survey B.M. 51, Elevation 883.75 on the Manitoba-Saskatchewan boundary.

As the land about the school will be used for playgrounds and gardens the system has been so designed that no structures appear above ground level. The sewerage system proposed will take care of 100 inmates.

After an examination of the conditions both from the cost and sanitary points of view it was decided that a sewerage system with only septic tank treatment would be sufficient and at the same time the most feasible.

Further treatment by disposal beds, of the sewerage after leaving the septic tank, was considered, but in addition to entailing a large extra cost the topography of the site is not suitable. Sewerage Disposal Beds to give satisfactory results should be near enough to the surface of the ground to allow of air action which is the main factor in the purification of the sewerage. As the ground surrounding the school is practically level the sewer will have to be laid at a depth of about eight feet. This would mean placing the disposal beds at this depth which is too deep for the securing of proper action from the air. From the sanitary standpoint the septic tank treatment of the sewerage should be sufficient as the affluent after passing from the tank will discharge directly
into the river where the dilution should be great enough to prevent dangerous pollution.

As shown on the General Layout Plan No. 1 it is proposed to take the drains from the laundry room at the rear of the building. The laundry waste and roof water are to be carried in a separate drain to a manhole below the septic tank, where it will then join the outlet pipe which will carry both it and the sanitary sewerage to the river. By this method, in addition to reducing the amount of sewerage to be treated, it ensures that no chemicals, etc., used in washing, enter the septic tank.

The sewerage from the toilets, baths, etc., is carried by a six inch tile (designated Sanitary on the Plan) to the septic tank, from whence it discharges into the river.

LAUNDRY WASTE.

As already stated the waste from the laundry is not treated but is discharged directly into the river. A six inch cast iron soil pipe carries the waste from the building to the double manhole "A". See details of manholes Plan No. 4. From this manhole a six inch tile is laid in the same trench as the sanitary sewer as far as the septic tank and from this point is carried round the septic tank to the outlet manhole "B" and thence into the river.

SEPTIC TANK AND SYPHON CHAMBER.

The sewerage, other than the laundry waste, leaves the building through a six inch cast iron soil pipe to the double manhole "A", thence through a six inch tile to the septic tank. As shown on Plan No. 3 the septic tank and syphon chamber are combined and are to be constructed of a 1, 2 and 3 concrete mix. To secure protection from frost a double plank roof with a six inch air space is provided.
The septic tank itself is seven feet wide, seventeen feet long and six feet deep at the centre. To facilitate the removal of sludge the bottom of the tank slopes towards the inlet end, and a manhole is placed in the roof at this point. The effluent enters the tank through a six inch cast iron soil pipe and by means of a tee and a short length of pipe is carried one foot below the sewerage line, thus avoiding any disturbance to the surface scum.

From the septic tank the sewerage flows over the dividing wall to the siphon chamber; two baffle boards carried one foot below the standing level of the liquid preventing any undue disturbance.

From the siphon chamber the sewage is discharged through two three-inch "Anthes" automatic siphons designed to discharge under an eighteen-inch head.

MANHOLES.

As shown on Plan No. 4 the manholes are constructed of concrete, with the exception of the roof which is made of two thicknesses of two inch planks. Each manhole is provided with a two feet square cast iron cover to allow of easy entrance.

Manhole "A" is a double manhole having two chambers separated by a concrete dividing wall, the one chamber taking the laundry waste and the other the sanitary sewerage. An iron screen is provided for the sanitary sewerage chamber to prevent any articles such as rags, boots, etc., reaching the septic tank.

In case it is desired to shut off the sewerage from the septic tank an opening between the two chambers with a sliding wooden gate is provided. The sewerage can thus at any time be diverted into the laundry drain and discharged directly into the river.
OUTLET.

In the vicinity where it would be feasible to place the sewer outlet a boulder shelf extends for some distance out from the shore. To lay a pipe through this, at a sufficient depth to prevent freezing, would be very expensive and to avoid this it is proposed to carry the sewage from the river bank in an eight inch square wooden box drain. The box drain would be made in sections about twelve feet long. With the rise and fall of the river a sufficient number of the sections will be taken up or laid down to carry the end of the drain to the river.

The other alternative is the laying of cast iron pipe far enough out into the river to ensure any possibility of freezing in the winter. This would entail expensive excavation through the boulder shelf and a certain amount of cofferdamming in the river itself. The cost for this will be quite high and for the present at least it is not considered necessary or advisable as the use of the wooden box drains though entailing a certain amount of labor should be satisfactory.

Dear Sir:

I have just received a letter from His Lordship Bishop Charlebois O.M.I. in connection with the completion of the Residential School at Sturgeon Landing and I take the liberty of bringing before you the subject of said letter with the hope that action will be taken if it is at all possible.

His Lordship states that last December Agent Waddy of The Pas suggested in a letter to the Department that the cement required for the foundations of Guy Residential School be freighted on the ice before the opening of navigation and that the contract for hauling gravel be let without delay for the same purpose. DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

MEMORANDUM: Mr. Scott.

Plans and specifications were prepared and tenders invited for the completion of the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, Sask., by advertising in the Regina 'Leader' and the Melfort 'Moon'. The tenders closed at noon today and in response the following have been received.

E. B. Sharpe, Minnedosa, Man. $86,329.00
R. N. Wyatt, Winnipeg, Man. $92,255.00
S. Brown, Winnipeg, Man. $93,900.00
A. Amyot, Hull, Que. $99,900.00
Wyndels Construction Co., St. Boniface, $112,300.00

An offer was also received from F. W. Graham of Moosejaw to construct the building on a cost plus 10% basis.

All of the above mentioned tenders are accompanied by the required deposit security with the exception of the tender of E. B. Sharpe. With reference to this tender a telegram was received from the Canadian Surety Company advising that they have issued a bid bond as his security. A telegram was received from Mr. Sharpe advising that he will arrange for a cash security in lieu of the bid bond. As the tender of Mr. E. B. Sharpe is the lowest and a reasonable price for the work, I beg to recommend that it be accepted.

A portion of the building was erected last year, which included boiler room and boilers, kitchen, power house, laundry, store rooms and chapel, the cost of which was $25,519.00. The cost of the building is necessarily high on account of its isolated location and the cost of freighting the materials by water from The Pas to Sturgeon Landing. There are funds provided in this year's vote for Indian Education for this building.

The above tenders include in addition to the building itself the complete installation of the water supply, sewerage disposal, and electric lighting systems.

I beg to call your attention to the matter of the engine for the new school at Sturgeon Landing, and to point out that the specifications call for a 10 H.P. engine 5 K.W. generator and 200 ampere hour battery for 32 volts.

We are putting this building in hand and promise to rush it to completion, but we are going to experience some difficulty in getting materials delivered on account of the low water in the rivers and lake. However, you can rest assured we will try and get out before we are frozen up again.

SIR: RE REPORT OF PROGRESS ON WORK ON INDIAN SCHOOL.

I take pleasure in submitting my report to the Department on the progress of the work done by Mr. R.N. Wyatt on his contract on above mentioned school.

The work on all concrete footings base of interior partitions, basement walls and piers for the posts in the basement was completed on July 7th. The gravel and sand used in this work was shipped from the other side of Sturgeon Lake and Marshall Point in barges and was up to the standard called for in the specifications.

The frame work is well advanced, the walls is sheathed to the height of the first floor joists on the outside with shiplap.

Ground floor joists framed in place and rough floor laid diagonally. All bearing partitions and posts and beams in place in the basement and ground floor.

First floor joists in place except for right side wing. Expect these will be in place Monday.

First floor walls is framed except for the right side wing.

The excavation for the trench for the four inch water intake pipe is well advanced. Work on the blasting of rock is making good progress.

Work on the excavation for the Septic tank was started on the 16th inst.

Work on the whole is progressing rapidly. There is thirty-seven men employed on the entire work. Owing to the low water at the start of the work, freight on the material was slow. But I am glad to report now that the high water mark is reached for navigation, the material is reaching here each (continued)

REPORT OF PROGRESS OF WORK.

I hereby take pleasure in making a second report to the Department on the progress of the work done by Mr. H. Wyatt on his contract on the above mentioned school.

Since my previous report the contractor has had an average of forty-five working on the various works, working twelve hours per day.

Carpenter work.

This work is now well advanced. The building is framed to the height of the ceiling of the second floor. All over the centre portion of building has the roof framed and the roof boards of shiplap nailed in place with cornice built. The exterior and interior of the outside frame walls is boarded up with shiplap to the height of the roof plate.

All the outside door frames and window frames in place. The siding has been started on the outside walls, right side elevation. The rough flooring has been laid diagonally on all the upper floors and all joists bridged across to specifications.

All studs bearing partitions are in place on all floors. Strapping of the inside of exterior walls in basement is now started.

Beam fillings on top of roof plates to underside of roof boards completed on centre portion of building.

The work of excavating for septic tank is now completed.

Outside drainage.

Plumbing is now under way with the six inch tile drain to tank. The six inch cast iron drain below basement is now in place. Joints packed with oakum and leaded but not tested out.

The plumbing work is going ahead with advantage before the shiplap is put on the ceiling.

Electrical work.

Work was started on the 29th of July.

Water intake pipe.

There is six hundred feet of the ditch completed to the depth required. There is 100 feet of rock blasting to be done yet, five feet deep through solid rock. Blasting operation in the ditch has been gaining for three weeks.

You will note that the various branches of the work is going on to advantage.

We expect the steam fitters here any time now to start on the heating. All the material for plumbing and heating is now on the site. I am well satisfied with the progress of the work to date during the past month.

Water proofing of the outside foundation walls from the top of the footing to the top of the grade line has been completed and the earth filled in according to specifications.

I have the honor to be Sir

July 27th, 1926.

R. Grant, Esq.,
Inspector of Construction,
Guy Indian School,
Sturgeon Landing, Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

This will confirm the decision we arrived at when I took up with you personally at Sturgeon Landing the question raised in your letter of July 9th, with reference to the water supply intake for the Guy Indian School.

In your letter you state that the plan of the water supply system shows the four-inch intake pipe to be some 700 feet long, whereas to reach the location shown on the plan as the point of intake would require 930 feet of four-inch pipe.

This discrepancy in the length of the four-inch intake pipe required was, as I pointed out, due to a misunderstanding as to the location of the school. In June of last year Mr. Patterson of this office visited Sturgeon Landing in company with Bishop Charlebois when two alternative sites for the school building were chosen by Bishop Charlebois and staked out by Mr. Patterson. These alternative sites "A" and "B" are shown on the blue print plan which I left with you.

Before designing the water supply it was necessary to know which of the sites had been chosen and the question therefore was taken up with Mr. Wyatt, contractor for the school, who stated that the site designated "A" had been decided on as the most suitable.

In estimating the cost of excavation Mr. Wyatt was requested to make borings along the proposed pipe line as Mr. Patterson with his limited equipment and help had not been able to determine how much rock excavation would be necessary. The borings were carried for 700 feet from the school building, which distance from site "A" would bring the intake well above the small point shown in white on the plan. As already stated, it was understood that site "A" had been chosen and the plans for both the sewer and water systems were therefore laid out for this site.

On receipt of your letter the question was taken up with Mr. Wyatt, who stated that this office must have been given the wrong location, as the lower site "B" had been chosen, and not site "A". This, of course, explained the discrepancy, as the distance between the two sites is about 200 feet.
As shown in red on the plan, with the actual location of the school at site "B", 700 feet of intake pipe would bring the point of intake in the bay, and not above the small point as originally proposed. In examining this point of intake on the ground with you it was found that there was very little current and we both agreed that it would be advisable to extend the four-inch intake about 125 feet, as at this point the current is quite strong a short distance from the shore.

In order to ensure running water at this point during periods when the river is low I pointed out to you that it would be advisable to clear the channel above of the loose rocks and boulders. By doing this a fairly good flow should be maintained, thus ensuring that the water will always be fresh at the point of intake.

I have taken this up with Mr. Wyatt and told him that you propose to take up the matter with the Department of Indian Affairs and recommend that the extension of the intake pipe and the clearing of the river bed above the point of intake be carried out.

Yours truly,

C. H. Attwood.

District Chief Engineer.

SIR,

Re-location of water intake well

In checking up the 4" water intake line we found that the location site of the well measured 936 ft, from the rear of the building in place of 700 ft, as per the plans & specifications.

I took the matter up with the dept of water & sewerage at Winnipeg, on receipt of my letter MR CRAIG answered it by making a visit here when he took the question of this discrepancy up with me personally, attached you will find his letter confirming the decision we came to with regard to the location of the well.

The contractor has the ditch made to the 700 ft mark and 380 ft, of 4" pipe laid in the trench the balance of the pipe will be laid when he completes the blasting of the rock near the school site.

I took the matter up with MR WYATT when he came here and asked him to give me a price on the additional work as outlined in MR CRAIG'S letter OF July 27th, his price is based upon a rock formation being encountered at the location selected for the well site it also include a the clearing of channel, of approximately 100 c,yds, of loose rock to ensure running water.

I would suggest that you give permission for me to have borings taken on the proposed site and along
the proposed pipe line from intake well to the water edge so that we could arrive at the actual cost of this work,

the proposed site for the intake well will be approximately 50ft, from the water this means an additional 30ft, of 8" C.I., pipe and 8ft, of 8" steel pipe its necessary to keep the well this distance from the river owing to the formation of the bank and protection for the pipe line from frost.

I am forwarding you the plan showing the site chosen for the building marked in red,

you will also see the proposed new location of the intake shown in red,

at the 700ft, mark the well would be 32ft from the river,

52ft south of the 700ft, mark there is a ravine crossing the pipe line to the full depth of the ditch if you decided to consider placing the intake at this point it would be best on the south side of the ravine, the water is the same depth approx, 18ft, but very little current to be of any advantage, far from the running stream to ensure fresh water at the intake.

MR WYATT submitted a price of $2,359.00 to complete the work, I would ask you to wire me if it is alright for me to proceed to make borings as i have outlined so that we will be in a position to check up on this price,

yours truly
