Sir:-

I have the honor to report that on my visit to the Guy Indian Residential School here today the following matters were drawn to my attention by Mr. R. Grant, Inspector of Construction.

1st. In regards to porch on right side elevation of building under construction, and the entrance to the boys wing, these two places should be screened in.

2nd. His Lordship Bishop Charlesbois asks for a stairway to be provided for an entrance to the sitting room in the girls wing.

3rd. The site for the stable is picked out by His Lordship east of left side elevation of building and the stable should be provided as the animals are already arriving here. Bishop Charlesbois has put up a one ply shed for temporary stable for one team but this will be no use for winter quarters.

4th. A root cellar will be required in addition to the small cellar in the main building. Mr. Grant has written you about need of drain for cellar in building.

5th. Outside toilets will be required for pupils arriving here before the sanitary arrangements are complete.

6th. A warehouse is required for storing supplies coming off the boat etc.

7th. Seating and necessary furniture for completing the chapel should be sent soon to allow of water transport being used as this is much cheaper than team work in the winter.

The Secretary,

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
I beg to suggest that favorable consideration be given to foregoing requirements. It can all be done cheaper at this time than after the contractor leaves, and could be done on cost plus percentage basis by contractor under supervision of Mr. Grant.

If these items are allowed I should be advised by wire as water transport will close in near future from lack of water on the lakes and rivers.

I am pleased to be able to report to the Department that the school is being put up in workmanlike manner and that the materials supplied seem to be first class. The building is now having the finish put on and of course will not go ahead as quickly as up to this time, but the contractor will have enough of it finished to allow the Principal to have some pupils enter the school by September 15th.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

P.S. On my return to The Pas to-day I received telegram of the 25th inst. regards lack of funds for stable. I presume this will also apply to the root cellar. Bishop Charlesbois will require lumber for floor, mangers etc of rough stable if the permanent one is not built at once.

Location of intake well shows formation of clay and boulders at depth of nine feet six inches. Ditch from well to shore line is 85 feet, test borings show loose rock at depth of six feet from surface, this formation shows the same from well to shore line.

The elevation of the ground at site of proposed well is 20'6" above lowest water level, the 4" pipe will be laid at depth of 14'10" below grade line where it enters intake well, this depth is caused through the grade line at point of well being high. The depth of the 4" pipe as laid at the 700 foot point completed by the contractor is down 8 feet, the location selected for the well is the best as there will be no interference with bends in the suction pipe, the distance is increased between the well and the shore line, it is also advisable to use the selected site for protection of the pipe line from frost; by bringing the intake well closer to the shore line it would mean that the pipe line would be too close to the embankment, and as I have said we do not want to have any fittings or bends in a pipe line the length of 825 feet from suction pump.

Referring to your wire of September 3rd I have arranged with the contractor for the shipment of the necessary materials only as required for the above work as outlined. In regards to the labor on this work I received a further estimate from the contractor of $6770.65, which included diverting the stream to ensure fresh water all winter at point of intake, but I considered this so excessive that I will not recommend it to the Department. I now recommend that we go ahead with the work under the contractor plus percentage you consider will be additional to his contract.

We are going ahead with this work on this basis to complete same as economical as possible, and on my return to Sturgeon Landing I will send a detailed estimate.

Your obedient servant,

Rodrick Grant

Estimate an additional work required

I have the honour to quote you my personal estimate on
the cost of doing the above work after making test holes
on the line of suction pipe alongside of the inflow pipe
from the source of supply to the site of the well,
test borings were taken on the site of the well.

First,

To excavate trench 125 ft., from the end the pipe
where the contractor finished to the location of the well,
to supply all pipe labour required,

Second,

To excavate trench 65 ft. from the intake well to a
point 20 ft. from the river, to supply 65 ft. of 8" cast iron
pipe and complete all labour,

Third,

The contractor advised me that he figured on the well
being sunk to a depth of 20 ft. below grade line at the
point located on the plan when he figured on the work of
the general contract, the new location of the well at grade
line is 20'6" above the lowest water level this means that
it will have to go down 30'6", in making up this estimate I
have allowed for the difference in excavating and concrete
required to complete this part of the work,

Fourth,

The contractor claims that he will require an
additional sum above his contract price for the labour
on the laying of the 20 ft. of cast iron pipe next the river
and connected to the steel pipe in the water as the
formation at this point he claims is rock, I have not allowed
this in my estimate, it will be adjusted later,

Fifth,

To clear the channel above the point of intake
of loose rock and boulders to divert the stream so that
the water will always be fresh at the point of intake,
Price to complete the additional work as outlined above

you will note that my price does not include any of the work

I have the honour to submit my report to you on the work done by Mr. R.M. Wyatt the contractor on the erection of the Guy Indian School, since I submitted my report of Sept 1st.

The work on the outside sewer drains is now completed except where the drain pipe leaves the septic tank for the manhole "B" this manhole has to be built.

Septic tank is complete with roof put on ready to be covered over with earth.

The water intake pipe is connected to the pump in the machinery room and the supply pipe brought from the pump to the floor of the tank house also the overflow pipe installed from the tank house to the boiler room and connected to the sewer, the tank house is built but not completed, the material is now on the job for the water tank but it is not assembled.

The basement is now completed except for the following items, cement base on outside walls, pipe covering which is now underway, to connect the wall radiators and interior painting on metal ceiling and all varnishing.

Ground Floor,

The work on this floor is now well advanced towards completion, the carpenter work is all done except for the finished floor in the corridor, the painting is being gone on with, and all hardware put on.

First Floor,

The plaster work is well advanced on this floor and at this rate is 50% complete, the carpenter work is ahead as far as it is possible until the plaster work is done, the work on the metal will go ahead as soon as the plasterers are through with this floor.
The second floor.

The balance of the lathing is not done on this floor, however, I expect they will be working on it in a few days; the plasterer completed three rooms.

Plumbing.

The plumbing work is well advanced under the conditions in which the plumbers are working not being able to complete one floor at a time, all toilet and bathroom fixtures in the basement are connected up complete, the toilet and bathroom fixtures on the ground floor are connected up to the extent of 75%, inside toilet and baths on the second floor has being connected up.

Heating.

This work is as well advanced that we are in a position to supply heat to all parts of the building when it turns cold at night time, I expect this part of the work to be complete in 12 days.

Electric work.

There is nothing to report on this work of any further advance being made since my report of Sept 1st, we have the generator and equipment here on the job and work of installing same will be proceeded with at once as the electricians are here.

Water intake.

Since the 13th of Sept we are busy working on this intake pipe lines and excavations for the well I expect to have the pipe here with the next beat which is expected here at the end of the present week, this is the part of the work that is holding us back we are our best to have the water to the building and the work completed outside.
before the freeze up or sooner if possible.

Outside work,

Owing to a shortage of materials we have been delayed in completing the siding on the front elevation and the right side elevation, the veranda on the side of the building is now being built. I expect the carpenters will be through with this work in a week's time so that we will have the painting completed. The work on the outside of the tank house is also going towards completion. I have arranged that the sisters have temporary accommodation with tables and anything they required for the children until such time as we will arrange for the permanent requirements. The work is going ahead with the same number of men working on the different trades.

I have the honor to submit herewith my report on the work done by Mr. R.N. Wyatt, the contractor, on the erection of the above mentioned school since I submitted my report of September 15th, 1926.

The manhole marked "B2" is complete with the pipes from the septic tank and the laundry running into it, with the discharge pipe from the manhole connected to the box drain discharging into the river. The roof of the septic tank is now covered with earth and graded over top.

The additional 135 feet of the water intake pipe is now laid in trench to well. The well is excavated to a depth of 22 ft. We have run into quicksand at this depth and had to stop operations until we could get suitable material for cribbing, which we expect to arrive here next week. The trench for the inflow pipe from the river to the well is now down 16 ft. Owing to the river rising 3 ft above the low water level, we are having difficulty in excavating to the depth required below the low water level mark.

We have connected a temporary pipe line from the river to the intake pipe at the well for a domestic water supply to the building. We are using the pumping plant in the machinery room which is now installed. The water is now installed and in use as it may be a few weeks before the intake is completed. I decided to have this temporary work done to accommodate the requirements of the building as it was quite a hardship on the Sisters, trying to attend upon the children without a water supply. It was also best to have the water tank filled before the cold weather set in so that any leaks would have a chance to take up before the frost came.

The basement.

The basement is now complete except for the following items, interior painting on metal ceilings and all varnishing on the woodwork, painting of all exposed steam pipes and radiators.

Ground floor.

There has nothing further been done on this floor except the painting of the rooms at the boys wing and class room #3. At present the children make use of this floor as it was the most advanced toward completion.
First floor.

The plaster work is now completed. The metal ceiling has been put throughout except in two rooms. The metal was left off these rooms until later as it was advisable owing to the waste and water pipes being exposed on the ceiling. Carpenter work of this floor, All door jambs set in place. Work to some extent has been done on window trim, also finished floor laid in sisters dormitory.

Second floor.

Plaster work all completed. Carpenters have not started work on finishing.

Plumbing.

The plumbing work is completed throughout the building to the extent of 80% of the contract.

Heating.

The work on the heating installation is now complete on all floors with all pipes in the basement covered as per specifications.

Electric work.

This work has been pushed ahead since my last report. The generator has been installed with the necessary equipment and now working but not completed.

Outside work.

The contractor is pushing the outside work before the cold weather comes on. Work is done grading around the building and finishing up all painting outside on main building and tank house and framed tower. Storm sash has all been fitted and now being painted. Carpenters are getting well completed with all details on the outside. The pipe box from the roof of the machinery room to the outside of the tank floor for the supply and overflow pipes is now being built. The steam line to tank room is also completed.

We have not done very much work on the inside except when the weather would not permit outside work.

I have the honor to submit my report for October 15th on the work done by Mr. R.N. Wyatt, the contractor, on the erection of the above mentioned school.

Since my last report the Contractor has completed all outside work on the main building except for the painting of verandas and small details.

Basement.
The painting has been started on this part of the building.

Ground floor.
No further progress has been made on this floor since my previous report. The children and staff are still occupying the basement and ground floor until the other floors are completed.

First floor.
No further progress has been made on this floor.

Second floor.
Work is well advanced on the metal ceilings. Bathrooms on this floor was finished to allow the plumber to put up his fixtures. Work has been started on the finishing.

Plumbing.
The plumbing installation is now completed. All fixtures connected up and all tested out satisfactory.

Painting.
All outside painting is well advanced including framed tower and tank house. A few days will complete this part of the work.

Grading.
Grading around building has been completed.

Roof troughing.
This work has been completed on the entire building.
lisional work on water intake.

No further progress has been made on the excavation for the well or inflow ditch from the river as we have not received the lumber required for the cribbing. The lumber arrived here on the 3rd but owing to the barge which carried this, breaking away from her cable and got away from the boat in a high wind and stranded across the lake. We expect to have this lumber delivered here about next Monday, when work will be pushed ahead. We have diverted and increased the stream by clearing the channel above the point of intake, of loose rocks and boulders.

Barn.

Work has been started on this and we expect it to be completed and ready for the housing of the stock in about one weeks time.

Electric installation.

Work on generator and equipment is now completed. Pumping machinery is installed complete and has been operating for the last three weeks and giving good service. The laundry machinery is now installed in the laundry and has been used with satisfaction.

Re work to be completed on main building.

We are going to finish complete the second floor before we ask the children to be moved from the ground floor. Then complete the first floor and finish up what was left off on the ground floor and basement.

The work inside will now go ahead as the outside work is now almost completed for the carpenters, the work to be done is carpenter work and painting. Heating and plumbing installation has now been completed as per specifications and is giving good satisfaction. I expect we will be into the cold weather before we can complete the permanent work on the intake water supply, if we had the lumber in time we would have been able to complete in milder weather.

SIR,

I have the honour to submit my report for October 30th, on the progress made on the work by Mr. Wyatt the contractor on the erection of the Guy Indian School.

The work of painting the verandas and details on the outside not completed at the time of my last report, is now finished.

The work on the 2nd floor is going ahead, the metalic ceiling is now complete on this floor including the painting.

The carpenters are working on the finishing and will be completed on or about the 15th of Nov., ready for the painters to start work on the varnishing as we have all the woodwork stained.

The children will be moved up to their dormitories just as soon as the painters are finished.

The painting work was advanced in the basement to the extent of finishing the girls wash room, toilets and recreation room.

The contractor expects to have all the interior work completed about the 15th of Dec.

The additional work on the water intake is now progressing we the well excavated down to the required depth, at the time of writing we have the concrete in the floor of the well and concrete in the walls up to the height of four feet, we had considerable blasting to do while excavating and at the depth of 8'6" below the lowest water level we struck bedrock, we are having the same formation in the ditch for the inflow pipe from the river, we are working at a disadvantage by having maintain the temporary water service to the school as the pipe line runs along the inflow ditch to the permanent pipe at the well.
this pipe line is exposed in the trench and makes it difficult to proceed ahead with the excavations. It will take us three or four weeks to complete the permanent work, as we are having zero weather and as low as ten below we find it much harder to maintain the present water supply.

All the work on the outside of the building is now complete.

The work on the barn is completed except for the floor; at present we are taking out bush timbers for this part of the work; there is now II head of cattle and four horses housed in the building for the past ten days.

We have also excavated for a root cellar as there was not sufficient accommodation inside for the potatoes and vegetables to be stored during the winter.

I may further state that we did no work on the ground and first floors since my last report.

I delayed my report as there was no mail service until the winter trail is open for travelling.

NOV, 27th, 1926

SIR,

PROGRESS REPORT

I have the honour to submit my report for Nov, 27th on the progress made on the work by Mr Wyatt the contractor on the erection of the Guy Indian School,

since I submitted my last report the carpenters completed all of the finishing work on the 2nd floor including the staircase at the boys end to the basement,

the painting work on this floor and the staircase is now finished,

the boys and girls will be moved up to their dormitories on the 30th of Nov, when all the painting work will be dry and ready to receive them,

the carpenters are now working on the first floor and will be finished in about 10 days,

the painting work is being done on the metal ceilings of this floor, also work on the varnishing has started,

there has being no further advance made on the finishing of the ground floor and basement since my last report,

all the cows and horse stalls in the barn has now being floored with a substantial timber floor taken from the bush and squared to make a solid floor under the stock,

the work on the water intake is going ahead, the concrete well is now completed and we are working on
excavations for the inflow pipe from the well to the river, I may say that we are having considerable difficulty with rock and quicksand in this ditch, the progress on the work is slow owing to that formation, we do not know for certain how much longer it will take us to complete this work as there is so much blasting of rock to be done and the trouble with quicksand and water that we have to keep pumps operating all the time, we are doing our best to have this work done as soon as possible, and we are endeavouring to keep the cost as low as possible, re-arranging the desks for the class rooms, just as soon as we have the children moved to their permanent dormitories on the top floor we will have the classrooms completed and the desks in place, at present the children occupies them for their dormitories, we expect the furniture here within the next two weeks also materials to make additional tables and cubboards not ordered outside.

I have the honour to be your Obedient Servant,

Rodrick Grant

I have the honour to submit my report for Dec. 15th, on the progress made on the work by Mr. Wyatt the contract on the erection of the Guy Indian School.

Since I submitted my last report, the carpenters completed their work on the finishing of the first floor; they are now working on the ground floor and basement finishing up the work left unfinished when the children arrived. I expect all the carpenter work to be completed about the end of the year.

The painting work is now well advanced on the first floor and will be ready for occupancy on the 20th Dec., when the sisters will move up to their permanent quarters.

The woodwork on the ground floor has to receive two coats of varnish except for class room #3 Indians room, and two bedrooms which had being finished previous to this floor being occupied. All floors has to be oiled or varnished as specified on this floor, metallic ceiling on the ground floor has to receive the finishing coat of paint on the ceiling of all the corridors.

The woodwork in the basement has to receive two coats of varnish throughout where stain and varnish is called for in the specifications, the painting is complete in the girls recreation room and toilets, washroom, the painting in the boys recreation room, toilets and washroom has not being started.

The metallic ceiling in the basement is complete to the extent 75% of the painting.

I expect the painting work to be complete before the 15th of Jan.

We have installed the new cook range for the
use in the kitchen.

The desks have been assembled and will be placed in the class rooms when finished painting.

We have not started on the work of installing the oven in the bakery as the space taken up with the oven was 9'x7' and the size of the bakery was limited for an oven this size. I waited until the Bishop arrived and took the matter up with him when he decided to have it installed in the bakery, as we have the brick here. We will start upon the work at once, the capacity of the oven is 300 loaves, we will install the dough mixer as soon as it arrives here.

The work of making the furnishings required in the way of tables for the dinning rooms, benches for same, and benches for the recreation rooms with hinged tops, also the fitting up of the kitchen and pantry, cupboards for all the dormitories, sewing room, platforms in the three class rooms will be started as soon as the material arrives. His Lordship Bishop Charlebois paid us a visit last week and told me that he wanted me to remain here until all the work of making the furnishings was complete. I told him that I would be here until the water intake was completed and if it was satisfactory to the dept., that I would remain and have all the work outlined above done, the items mentioned above does not include any of the furnishings made outside.

The seating accommodation in the chapel is being arranged for as per your instructions.

Re: the water intake

We are working on this work through the cold weather and are now getting close to the river, it is impossible to say when we will have this completed as we have so many difficulties to contend with and it is work on which you can't use many men.

SIR,

PROGRESS REPORT

I have the honour to submit my report for dec, 31st, on the progress made on the work by Mr Wyatt the contractor on the erection of the Guy Indian School.

Since I submitted my last report the carpenter work on the finishing has been completed throughout the building.

The work on the painting is well advanced in the basement and ground floor and should be completed on the 15th of Jan.

The balance of the window shades to be fixed in the rooms not finished by the painters will be done when these rooms are completed.

Re- the water intake,

The work has been going ahead every day and I expect we will reach the river in about 10 days when we will prepare for the coffer dam in the river before we can excavate for the pipe. This work should be completed sometime about the 20th of Jan.

With regards to the water supply during the time we have been on the construction of water intake, we have kept the house supplied with water through the system by the pumping plant and there has being no trouble with the frost on the intake line from the well as we have pumped all the water from the well since we had it completed in Nov. We are in a position to keep the house supplied with water until we open the valve on the inflow pipe from the river when we have the work completed.

Re- installation of oven,

We have made a start on this work and it is well advanced although we were delayed for material.

The work is also started on the furnishings and we are having them done for the rooms that require them made first.

Dear Sir,

I beg to call your attention that a bell will be needed for the Residential Guy school. They cannot do without a bell, but I do not see any place in the building provided to put it. You could call the attention of the Department on this fact.

I think the best would be to put up a little tower in the centre of the building in which the bell could be placed. Please see about this before you get through your work in the school.

I beg to remain yours truly,

+ O. Charlebois, P.A.
Bishop of Keewatin.
SIR,

Please find attached letter from Bishop Charlebois drawing my attention that they require a bell for the Guy School, as there was no provision made on the plans for a tower to house a bell. I would recommend to the dept. that they consider placing this tower on the main roof of the centre portion of the building, centre line of bell tower to be on centre line of building, design of tower and roof of same, to conform with the construction of the main roof design. I would prefer that this was done now while I am here as I understand that a bell has been purchased and will be shipped here very soon. By placing the bell on the centre line of the building it would be operated in the main corridor on the ground floor.

I have the honour to be your obedient servant,

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to the providing of a belfry for the Guy School, I beg to say that you may arrange to have a small belfry built on the roof of the passage leading from the school to the chapel. A suitable covering can be provided in this location for the bell at a cost not exceeding $60.00, the bell rope to be taken down and operated from the passage leading from the school to the chapel.

It is not considered advisable to place a belfry on the main building as this would cost considerably more in order to keep it in proportion to the building.

I have the honor to enclose the final estimate for R.N. Wyatt for the Guy Indian Residential School. The Inspector of Construction says there are a few minor items to be given the final touch but he is satisfied to sign this final estimate. His letter is attached.

My opinion is that it is satisfactory as the men have their own tools on the job and that Mr. Grant will push the work of completing the extras and clean up the whole operation, but I would feel satisfied if the Department will give an opinion one way or the other.

Feb. 9, 1927.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo enclosing certificate No 6 for payment to Mr. Wyatt on his contract for the Guy Indian Residential School. This certificate has been changed to $15,000.00, and cannot be considered, therefore, as a final certificate. The final certificate will have to show and include all extra work that has been authorized, and should be accompanied by a statement showing how the various amounts are made up.

With reference to the erecting of cupboards, shelves, etc., if Mr. Grant can undertake this work himself the Department would be prepared to retain him for this work, providing same did not exceed two months. This would probably work out more economically than by using Mr. Wyatt's carpenters.

Dear Sir:

I thank you very kindly for your prompt answer on the 10th Inst., to my wire of the same date.

I received your remittance of Fifteen Thousand Dollars ($15,000.00), but the Certificate calls for Fifteen Thousand Five Hundred and Thirty Five ($15,535.00), kindly let me know what happened to the Five Hundred and Thirty Five Dollars ($535.00), and would like to have your check for this amount, and now that the Contract is completed I should have my deposit check returned.

Your Inspector on the job being Scotch exercises all the qualities of their race when it comes to issuing Certificates, one would think it was his own money he was paying out. You can readily understand that I was entitled to further money after September than he gave me as we had the School inhabited by the 15th September and could have been easily finished by the Contract time had we not done the extra work outside, which we wanted to get done to protect ourselves from suffering from the cold. This also assisted the Department in saving time on extra cost of doing this work in cold weather. Our bill for extras will amount to a considerable sum and presume that he will not want to give me any
further payment until we are through although I am asking for it and by the way the work is going and the amount of extra's that are continually cropping up we will not be through until the 1st of April. Of course we have not many men working there now as the cost would be too great in shipping any more men.

Kindly see that these checks are issued at your earliest convenience, I am

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the payment on your last certificate, I beg to say that it was necessary to hold back $500.00 from this certificate in order that it would not be considered a final certificate. All extra work performed by you, in order to be considered, will have to be shown on the final certificate. It is not necessary of course to wait until all of the work is completed in order for you to obtain an advance on the extra work, provided everything is in order. Your deposit security cannot be released until thirty days after the completion of the contract. Re - Guy Indian School Sturgeon Landing, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Your favor of the 21st ultimo, received while I was away from the City temporarily and it could not be answered until now.

The principal difficulty of financing the work at Sturgeon Landing lies with the Extra's of which the total amount will run to between Twenty and Twenty Five Thousand Dollars.

I was at Sturgeon Landing in the last week of January and of course asked Mr. Grant, the Inspector in charge, to certify an appropriate proportion of my outlay on these Extra's; but for some reason unknown to me that was not done, and I now ask that you give consideration to the difficulties of the situation thus imposed on me.

Your letter in reference allows that an advance on the Extra work is due to me; but, also stated that the Extra work in order to be considered will have to be shown on the final Certificate, yet because it is impossible to state when the final Certificate will be issued there appears to be some degree of inconsistency in the conditions thus laid down. I therefore desire to appeal to you for relief which is absolutely necessary and in the circumstances properly due to me.

I note the reason why you send me Fifteen Thousand Dollars by check just recently instead of the Fifteen Thousand Five Hundred and Thirty Five Dollars as certified by Mr. Grant. Do you not think that a much smaller sum, say the odd Thirty Five Dollars would serve the purpose indicated in your statement. Then as Mr. Grant has certified to the full amount of the Contract, same being complete in every respect to his satisfaction, there does not appear to be any reason for holding the deposit security and I hope to receive that at once because the date of Mr. Grant's certificate was Feb. 1st 1927, and the thirty days mentioned in your letter is now nearly expired.

Personally I am of the opinion that the security deposit and at least Five Hundred Dollars from the amount you have retained out of the total of Mr. Grant's certificate dated February 1st, can be sent to me at once according to your letter of the 21st, and

Sir,

In reference to the contract for the Guy Indian Residential school I beg to say that I reported at time the final estimate was put in that a day or so of work was required to finish up the water pipe etc. As Mr. Grant reported lately to the Department, Wyatt has not yet put in this length of pipe. It seems the easiest thing in the world to do this, but it is not by any means a snap. Wyatt's crew has put in about two months trying to get excavated a spot of clay and boulders six feet long and one foot deep, and to get his crib work water tight to put in the length of pipe. The rock bottom has cracks through which the whole force of the current is forcing water, and at the day of my visit four large pumps could not hold back the flow. The foreman is about disgusted and I would not wonder if he pulls off the job.

If he does pull out we will probably get someone to tackle the work and finish it, though we may have to wait till summer when the water is tame enough for a chap to get right in and do little spade work in his pelt, but not by any means what I would call an impossible situation.

Your letter #132-7-12 of the 9th of February instructed me to take Wyatt's men off extras and furnishings etc and I told Mr. Grant to do this, since then he has worked alone, see my other report on furnishings.

The purpose of my visit was to get the extras and contract cleaned up to March 1st as there has been lots of time to do this. However Mr. Grant has not been able to get the contractors figures done so where he wants them yet and they have not been presented in voucher form. I wished to get them all in for this fiscal year but the contractor has nothing ready so they will have to stand over.

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Waddy:

Re work required to complete the job as requested by the Principal and Sister Superior.

Basement. To stain and varnish the cupboards already built and to build 15 more lockers in girls playroom. One cupboard 12" deep x 3'x6'. Kitchen. One cupboard 12" deep by 3'x6". In Father's Sisters and Men's dining room one cupboard each.

In scullery. One table with drawer and bread cutting shelf. Covering the bottom of stairs in basement. The Principal asks that these two openings be closed with v joint and doors supplied. This is to ensure privacy from the boys and girls who are inclined to wander through the building when they are left in the recreation rooms.

Painting in kitchen and pantry. Put paint on over the keene cement and on the metal ceiling in the kitchen; this is very dirty.

Ground floor. Desk platform in Class Room #3. The Principal also requests that we close up the opening between the 3r girls room and corridor with a doorway 7' high. This will keep the Indian visitors who visit this room from wandering around, and will also give the visitors a record to themselves at this end of the building as well as the other end.

First floor. Closets made. One cupboard 12" deep x 14"x10' with hat and coat hooks for each girl.

Sewing room. One cupboard 12" deep x 10"x20'.

In corridor to chapel balcony. One blanket cupboard, for use of staff. 18" deep x10"x18'. With doors.

Sister's living room balcony. Bench on hinged strips.

Second floor. Boys dormitory. Cupboard under wash basins to hold boots etc. One cupboard for blankets 18" deep x10"x12', with doors on all cupboards.

You will see from this that there is quite a lot of work to be completed; I would like to have it done by break up; you will have to arrange for the materials to come at once if the work is to be done. I have put on a painter to help me finish the job; he will have about fifteen days work, this was necessary as I want to get the job through.

The Principal mentioned the following. There are no facilities here for drying clothes in the winter and they are using every empty room here to dry the laundry. If the Department will allow this I could have one made here suitable for their requirements, in the meanwhile I will do nothing about it except get prices on materials which would be required, and when I get this here I will advise you.

I hear you are coming up here soon and at that time I will go into all these matters personally with you.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

Re water intake.

I have the honor to report to you on the above work that the extra 65 feet of eight inch inflow pipe laid from the well was complete on the 10th of January last. On the completion of the laying of this pipe I came inside and worked on the extra furnishings. During part of the months of January and February I had to get help from the men who worked for the contractor as the demand to have this work done was urgent, I had to get the work done that was most required.

Since the end of February I have been working alone on receipt of your instructions through Mr. Waddy. This was on furnishings.

During the time the 65 feet of pipe was being laid I had to keep continually on the job outside. The contractor started into work where we left off laying pipe as per his contract. At the end of January he had all his pipe laid with the exception of the last length of steel pipe in the river. He had the coffer dam ready for pumping out, but unfortunately owing to the rock bottom in the river he could not get the dam tight to get the excavation finished for this length of pipe, he had only to go down two feet for the distance of six feet when the deep water would have been reached. To date he has only been able to excavate one foot. To make connections with the pipe laid it will be necessary for him to go down this other foot so that the pipe will be deep enough at the lowest water level for the protection from frost. I am sorry that he is having such trouble, he has worked every workable day since the end of January, we have had four pumps working and cannot get the water low enough to finish excavating but we are hopeful that we will have this completed any day now. We have expected every day since the last of January that that would clean up the job. I am enclosing copies of letters forwarded to Mr. Waddy in reference to furnishings. I am working on plan of present water line and sewage line as they were changed on account of the building not being on the spot noted on the plan. These will be for your file for future reference.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM:

MR. McLEAN,

In view of the distance of the new Guy Indian Residential School from markets, the Department authorized Bishop Charlebois to get whatever equipment was necessary for the satisfactory conduct of the school and to present receipts to the Department. Reimbursement has already been made for many articles which His Lordship purchased to advantage. He bought a bell for the school, however, which is a more expensive type than usually secured for this purpose. It was purchased from the Meneely Bell Company, of Troy, New York State, and the cost was $555. There was no duty on the equipment.

As His Lordship had carte blanche authority and in no other case was it abused, I am inclined to recommend reimbursement, particularly as he made a special plea when in Ottawa last week. I should be grateful for your instructions.

Russell Heines

Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir;-

I am in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School in which he asks that the following buildings be constructed at that school.

Warehouse 15'x20' walls 10'.
Build root cellar in place excavated 15'x30'.
Chicken house 15'x40' walls 10'.
Ice house 16'x20' walls 10'.
Carpenter-machine-blacksmith shop 20'x50' walls 12'.
House to accommodate visiting parents etc. 16'x30'x8'.

The Principal has sent me list of material required for the above work, but no plans of the buildings so I am not able to figure on the cost of labor. His list of lumber, brick, cement, paint, hardware, freight etc would come to about $5000.00, and the labor might amount to probably $2000.00.

The Department, after considering whether the buildings are to be constructed, might advise what policy is to be planned in reference to labor, or whether contract work will be considered.

During June and July it will be impossible for me to overlook any construction as I am absent paying annuity.

Day labor is not satisfactory unless the workmen are under close supervision.

Mr. R. Grant made out the list of material for Fr. Doyon, and when he comes through The Pas on his way home next week I will have him make sketches of each building, and have the matter put in shape to submit to contractors if so desired, or to submit them to the Department.

I enclose the lists of material sent here, and will be obliged if they are returned when the Department checks them over and approves or cancels them.

The Principal asks for 25 rolls barbed wire, this will be purchased under instructions in letter 132-7-14. The canoe he asks for on last sheet of estimates enclosed is for use while fishing.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir;-

Sir:

Material used on Barn.

The attached account is for the supply of all material used in the erection of a completed barn 28' X 50' with concrete footings, roof, height of ceiling from stable floor 6' 0", height of hay loft from floor shaft to ridge 22'. Estimated quantities of material were gotten out at first for a building complete except for the drop siding and shingles. The shiplap on the outside was to be covered over with tar paper and held with lath and the same on roof. As the stock was on the ground the Bishop wanted the work done at once and would prefer a completed job which was given except for the outside painting, he was afraid that a temporary building would not be suitable. The size of the building was approved by the Bishop and the site was chosen by him. The floor of the barn is well laid with bush timbers well hewn which makes a solid floor. Electric light and water is installed.

Yours truly,

Sir:

Attached account for the additional work on the water intake including the construction of the well and the laying of 32 feet of inflow pipe at the river as per the contract.

I would refer to my estimate of September 14th on the cost of doing the additional work.

1st Supplying and laying 125 feet of 4" Gal. pipe from the point 700 feet from the building to the well.

2nd Supplying and laying 65 feet of 8" pipe iron pipe from the well to the river.

3rd The additional depth of the well.

4th I made no allowance in my estimate for the supplying and laying of the 32 feet of pipe at the river.

5th Clearing the channel above the point of intake.

The Contractor's account for excavations for the 4" pipe on the water line does not include the supply of the pipe as this was charged for on another account. The depth of the 4" pipe where it enters the well is 14' 6" below grade line and 9' where connected to the pipe at the point 700 feet from the building.

The well is down 30 feet from the roof to the floor of the well. The Contractor's bill includes the construction of the whole well and all material and expense. It also includes the lumber used in cribbing the well and the lumber used in cribbing the 65 feet of ditch to the river.
After a depth of 14 feet was reached we had to drill through rock and quicksand all the way down and at 7' 6" below the water level we came upon solid rock. It was slow work excavating from 14 feet below the grade line to the bottom of the well we had to dynamite every foot of the way and put in tight cribbing owing to the quick sand. The contractor deducted the amount he figured on in the contract.

The account for laying the 65 feet of 8" pipe does not include the cost of supplying the pipe which was charged for in another bill. The formation in the ditch below the river was the same as the well. It had to be cribbed tight all the way owing to the water and quick sand. Pumps were in use all the time we were working.

The account for laying the 32 feet of pipe to the river and work on the cofferdam I may say that the Contractor had great difficulty in getting the cofferdam tight in the river owing to the rock bottom the water coming in through the bottom where they were excavating.

With regard to the lay out of the work I have forwarded plan to the Dominion Water Supply Department, Winnipeg, for them to alter their plans to show the work as it was laid. No doubt you will have received a copy of the corrected plans by now.

Below you will find cost of the additional work as per my estimate of September 4th.
To excavating trench 125 feet $284.96
To additional work on construction of 10 feet of well 662.00
To excavation for 65 feet of 8" pipe 1661.00
To 125 feet of 4" pipe and 65 feet of 5" pipe 499.71
To diverting stream 500000

$4147.67

With the above information and referring to your wire of September 3rd and my letter of September 9th you will be able to arrive at the amount which should be paid to the Contractor for this work.

You will note that the accounts do not show a charge for gasoline except for six gallons purchased from the trading store. As we had the pumps running every day there must have been a considerable quantity used up. The gasoline was supplied by the principal. It looks as if he did not put in his bill to the contractor.

Yours truly,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

Re Temporary Water Line.

We had to maintain a temporary water service to the building during the winter while we worked on the water intake. We were able to supply water to the school all winter except for three weeks in December; it was very fortunate that we were able to supply the entire building with water. Otherwise it would have been bad for the sewerage and drainage system, as it was impossible for the occupants to use the outside toilets all the time. During the time we were unable to supply the house, water had to be carried from the river.

I appreciate the assistance that I received from the Contractor in helping maintain the water supply during operation on water intake.

Sir,

I beg to state that on my official visit to the Guy Indian Residential School on August 19th, 19th and 20th, I went into matters very fully with the Principal, as he was complaining that certain things had not been completed before the Inspector of Construction left there. I will come to these later on in this letter.

The Sister Superior asked if she could be supplied with a typewriter. The Principal has a typewriter but he is located at a different end of the building to the Sister Superior and she does most of the office work, and states that it is necessary that she be supplied with one of these machines if the Department will be pleased to grant one.

At this time I wish to mention that His Lordship Bishop Charlebois, who was at the school, extends his thanks to the Department for all the favors which have been shown to him and his people while the school was being built and he said he could not express his thanks fully enough to cover all the favors he has received.

Starting the examination of the building in the basement, the laundry requires doors on the clothes cupboards; it also requires an ironing board 3' x 12', to be attached so pulleys so it could be attached to the ceiling and be out of the way when not in use. The bake shop requires a thermometer on the oven, which is made by McQuaid & Roberts, and the baker asks if she could be supplied with a fiber washtub for setting the yeast before she mixes up the dough in the dough mixer. She also asks for a tin box which would hold about fifty loaves, for keeping bread fresh. The principal asked for lock checks for the outside doors, but I noticed in your letter of the 11th inst. that these are refused. In the Brothers' dining room two small cupboards are asked for to hold the dinner, etc., and a cupboard is also asked for to keep the athletic goods for the boys' play room. These could be made on the premises if material is supplied. The Principal also asks for a small door to be placed under the main stairs in the boys' part of the basement, just a V-joint affair; he also asks for a drip basin under the tap in the boys' play room. In the school rooms all the seats have not been attached.
to strips. Two of the rooms will require four hundred linch feet $1 \times 3$, with six gross screws nails to attach the seats in sets of four. The Principal asks about the shelves on the shelves of his library in his room; he also asks for a desk lamp for his office; shelving is required in the cupboard in the junior class room; the Sister Superior also asks for a large hand bell to use in the corridors to call the pupils and the staff; the cupboards in the clothes cutting room are not all varnished, and they require staining and hooks and eyes; the partition at the bottom of the stairs on the girls' side of the building requires to be varnished; the girls' recreation room requires a cupboard of v-joint and also requires about twenty more small individual lockers which could be used as seats and for the use of the girl pupils. The Principal asks for two sewing machines for this room, but I see by your letter of August 12th that these have been refused. The Sisters dining room also requires a cupboard for the dishes; the laundry department of the school were asking for a dryer for drying clothes; His Lordship Bishop Charlebois is asking for a steam engine and boiler in place of the gasoline engine, so he says it would be more economical to run and would give more power. If this is supplied eventually the steam could be used in the dryers. The matter of the steam engine will be taken up later on. I am getting information regards costs, etc., of same before I bring it officially to the attention of the Department. In the girls' sewing room three benches 16' long are required; in the same room the cupboards required to be varnished and the doors of the cupboards require to be stained and varnished; On the veranda used by the sisters four benches are required, with folding legs so that they can draw down alongside of the wall and be out of the way when he stands or walks around on this veranda, where they take their exercise. The cupboards in the hall, which leads to the balcony of the chapel have not been varnished and stained. This should be completed. The Principal also asks if window stripping of some sort can be supplied for the windows, to keep the draft out in the winter; on the third floor three clothes closets are required for staff rooms. These are on order in Regina since last fall and I had a letter this week saying they are being supplied. V-joint doors are required under the basins in the dormitory of the boy's room. One set of three doors and springs in the same room; small boys' dormitory ditto; small girls dormitory ditto. There is a hole leading to the roof, in the ceiling of the third floor, and the sisters store a lot of material in the space between the roof and the ceiling. In order to reach this place the Sisters ask for a ladder on hinges and free at one end, and the free end of the ladder could be attached to a pulley and pulled up out of the way when not in use.

In the boys' dormitory on the first floor there are no basins, toilets, or cupboards. It is absolutely bare except for the beds. Mr. Grant did not draw my attention to this before he left, so I presume he thought it was satisfactory. However, these pupils will require basins, toilets and cupboards.

The Secretary - 2.
The pipe line was extended across a valley, which was filled in with earth, and the filling is now acting as a dam to hold back the water which comes from the surrounding country. In order to allow this water to escape and to save the filling from washing into the river, it will be necessary to place a galvanized pipe or culvert to carry away the excess water. This pipe should be 36" long and at least 18" in diameter. If this has not supplied the whole lot of the filling put in will be washed away and the water system exposed. There also should be some back filling done on the pipe line, which was put in during the winter. This is now settled considerably and it should be filled in level with the surrounding ground. I think it would cost probably $20.00 or $25.00 to make a job of this.

From the school grounds slopes gently towards the barn, and in between these places all the water from both places collects and during a storm it runs off very quickly. Twice this summer the water has cut a gulch between the school and the barn and has been levelled both times. In order to avoid this it will be necessary to put in 150 feet of 8 inch tile with a small catch basin where most of the water collects. This will drain the water down to the bank of the river and avoid any unsightly washouts in the future.

The Principal asks to have the hay loft lighted with electricity. This would require 75 feet of flexible conduit, a switch box, 3 outlet boxes, one blank cover, and some other attachments.

The school has shipped me in one 10" pulley, which they want to exchange for a 16" pulley to speed up the dough mixer. The first pulley supplied was not quite suitable. They also shipped me in an 8" pulley for the generator, as being too large, and asked me to have it brought down to a 7½" pulley. If I receive authority from the Department I can ship these two pulleys to Winnipeg and exchange them there. The expense for this should not be very heavy.

The Principal asks for a 40 foot extension ladder to use along the eavestroughing when it gets clogged up with snow and ice in the spring and fall. He also asks for some solder and a half gallon of muriatic acid for repairing the eavestroughing.

An extra length of 8" pipe will be required for the water intake. It should be on hand at the school to be placed in position any time the water gets low in the river.

The Principal of the school asks if threshold strips can be placed on all the doors leading off the corridors in the school into each room. He states that the draft in the building draws all the dust and dirt from the corridors into the rooms. This was not done during construction and the Department might consider the advisability of having them put in.

The material required for many of the cupboards, doors, etc., mentioned in this letter appears to me to be similar to what was allowed the Principal in your letter of the 11th August, and before I supply him with this material which has been authorized I will find out if that is what the material was for, so there will be no duplication of material.

I think I am leaving the worst trouble for this last paragraph. When I was at the school I naturally walked down to the kitchen to see how the Sisters were getting on in cooking the immense pile of food necessary to feed all the Indians and white people who had been invited to the official opening, and was surprised when I got to the kitchen to find the sisters paddling around in four inches of water all over the kitchen floor and then told me that there had been water standing in the kitchen at times during the last summer; that every time it rained the water came in under the floor and along the outside wall. It appears to me that Wyatt or Wyatt's men slipped some considerably big stones into the cement at this point and the wall and floor just here are not water proof. On account of the lateness of the season I thought it wise to let the job of clearing the river so as to divert more water to the intake supply. Dear Sir:

Your letter September 14th., re $500.00 account paid to E. Hagen. On account of the lateness of the season I thought it wise to let the job of clearing the river so as to divert more water to the intake supply. As the water was so cold at that time of year it was pretty hard to get men to work in it and as Mr. Hagen had some of his fellow countrymen who, he had in his employee, he was willing to take the job. The amount to clear was a width of about 25' and 100' long, and the estimated amount of rock to be removed was 100 yards. This had to be taken out of at least two feet of water. I estimated 100 yards at $6.00 per yard and think you will agree the price was reasonable, in fact Mr. Hagen did not any more than make wages. In my action Mr. Roderick Grant your Inspector concurred.

Trusting this information will be what you require,

I am

Yours truly,
J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Sir:

Your letter of Sept 14th with reference to statement of account sent in by R.M. Wyatt, Contractor on certain work done at the Guy School, Sturgeon Landing, has been forwarded to me from my home address at Prince Albert, and which I received today.

You will find in my estimate of Sept 14th 1926 to the Department on the additional work required to complete the water intake, that the fifth item deals with the work mentioned in your letter and was carried out by R.M. Wyatt, the general Contractor who had subcontracted the work to Mr. Hagen, who had the work done. Mr. Wyatt asked me at the time if it was all right for him to get Mr. Hagen to do the work on contract. I told him that it was perfectly all right providing the work did not cost more than $500.00. The channel was cleared of trees and rocks located sufficiently to divert the stream and have a stronger current at the point of intake as specified.

I remember Mr. Hagen complained about the work being so difficult to undertake at that time of the year. I knew that he gave full value in his work.

Dear Mr Waddy:

Re- Root-Cellar

I am enclosing herewith the Return os Labour for the Root-Cellar. I am surprised myself seeing how much it costed to have that root-cellar completed, but I am presenting to you the real amount of money I did spent for that work.

On the starting, laborers had to dig for a few days, though the digging had been done last Fall. Then the work on the walls and the roofing. After the cement walls done, we had that heavy rain for a week; As there was no drain in the root cellar, the walls cracked and bent. We had to put a wall of logs around the inside cement walls and then to put the roof. This took lot a time and lot a money. However the root cellar will be very good.

I didn't take any saw-dust, because when the Toben came here I asked Harmenn, the captain if there was any saw-dust across the river, and he told me that there was none. So it was too late to wait.

I have about 75 bags cement left

I am sending you the cost for the gravel hauled. I paid the that amount Cash. There is some more gravel left also

Will it be possible for a dentist to come here before freeze up. So many teeth to be fixed.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.
The Pas, Man.

The root house is straight cement walls with lumber roof, filled in on top with earth.

Winnipeg, Manitoba,
November, 1927.
By John Craig.
REPORT ON
WATER SUPPLY
FOR
GUY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
STURGEON LANDING, SASKATCHEWAN.

Winnipeg, Manitoba,
November, 1927.

by John Craig.
INTRODUCTORY.

On October 14th, 1927, the Department of Indian Affairs was advised that the water supply of the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing had been condemned requested that an engineer of this Branch visit the school and submit a report covering the question. Following instructions from Mr. Johnston to this effect the undersigned visited the school on October 27th and 28th and in company with the Principal, Reverend Father Doyen, made an investigation and inspection of the school water supply.

PRESENT WATER SUPPLY.

The water supply is taken from the river some 325 feet above the school. At this point an eight-inch wrought iron intake pipe extending five feet into the river carries the water to a concrete intake well thirty feet deep located about one hundred feet from the shore. From the intake well the water is drawn through a four-inch suction pipe to the school.

The present trouble with the source of supply is due to the intake pipe only extending five feet from shore instead of from twenty to twenty-five feet, as instructed, to ensure the point of intake being in the current. Five feet from shore there is no current owing to a small point of land immediately above and the supply is therefore drawn from comparatively still water. The manure which the school authorities complain of is the remains of that used by the contractor in his efforts to seal the cofferdam and which had never been properly
removed. With the end of the intake only five feet from the shore and in still water it will naturally take some time for this trouble to disappear, unless steps are taken to remove the manure.

The question of the distance necessary to extend the intake into the river in order to reach the current was taken up personally with the Inspector, Mr. Grant, in July of last year when the writer visited the school for this purpose. At that time the matter was fully gone into and instructions were given that the intake pipe was to be carried at least twenty feet out from the shore in order that the point of intake would be in running water.

In Mr. Grant's letter dated August 31, 1927, to Mr. Waddy, Indian Agent at The Pas, copy of which is enclosed, he stated that owing to the difficulty of sealing the cofferdam at the water end of the intake the contractor could not make the necessary rock excavations for the last 22 feet of trench, with the result that, as shown on the accompanying plan, this length of pipe was not laid to the proper grade, but has a gradual rise from the eight-inch valve to the end of the pipe in the water. Mr. Grant points out that with the water end of the pipe gradually rising, the further the pipe was extended the nearer it would come to the surface, and as no bends or fittings were available he decided to carry the pipe only a short distance from the shore. In his letter to Mr. Waddy Mr. Grant recommends that the pipe be extended some four or six feet and by using a sixteenth bend correct the upward slope of the present intake.

In his letter to Mr. Waddy Mr. Grant recommends that the pipe be extended some four or six feet and by using a sixteenth bend correct the upward slope of the present intake.
COMMENTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS.

It should be pointed out that with this intake length of pipe not laid to the proper grade the danger from frost at the water end of the intake has been largely increased, and though it may not now, under the circumstances, be necessary to re-lay this section to the proper grade extra precautions will have to be taken each fall to protect this section of the intake from freezing. To provide a proper intake it will be advisable to have the present pipe extended some fifteen or twenty feet further into the river where, as shown on the plan, the end of the pipe will be in six feet of water at the present stage of the river and well out into the current. It will be noted that Mr. Grant fears that by extending the present pipe further than four to six feet out there will be danger of the outer end being broken by ice or other debris. If the pipe is properly covered with earth, brush and rock, however, no trouble from this cause need be feared. This covering will also provide a measure of protection from freezing, though an additional covering of brush and snow should be placed over the intake each fall.

In extending the pipe one of the following methods may be used in order that the extension will properly follow the bed of the river. (a). Putting on a ninety degree bend on the end of the present intake and with a short nipple connecting it to another ninety degree bend. By this means a flexible joint is secured and the necessary added extension of the intake can be raised or lowered as desired. (b). Flexibility can also be obtained by placing a flexible joint at the end of the present intake and the extra length of pipe can then be lowered to conform with
the bed of the river. As the ninety degree bends are cheaper than a flexible joint and more easily obtained the first method is probably preferable.

In taking up the question with Father Doyen it was agreed that owing to the lateness of the season it would be inadvisable to extend the intake during the winter, but as soon as possible next year after the high water had passed this work should be done. With reference to the contamination of the water caused from the remains of the manure left in the cofferdam, it was pointed out to Father Doyen that this must be fairly well diluted by now and with the forming of the ice this source of trouble should be considerably reduced. No sickness has been traced to the water supply but it was further pointed out to both Father Doyen and Mr. Waddy that it would be advisable to have an analysis of the water made and if from this analysis it was found that contamination existed then chlorine in some form should be used in the water supply until the intake is extended.

It may be stated with reference to this installation that this office was not requested to supervise the construction but only to submit a report and plans covering the installation. In July 1926, owing to the change in the location of the school, there appeared a discrepancy in the length of the suction main and the point of intake. Mr. Grant wrote to this office with reference to this matter and the undersigned immediately visited the school and discussed with Mr. Grant the location of the intake and the necessity of extending the intake pipe into the current and deep water. This was not done and the manure was not removed which is the cause of the present trouble.
Another point raised both by Mr. Waddy and Father Doyen was the slipping of earth on the river bank along the line of the suction main. This sliding as shown in the accompanying photographs occurs a short distance south of the intake well and is taking place along a stretch about two hundred feet long. Though not agreeing with Father Doyen, who states that the whole river bank is slipping, the sliding which has occurred so far is quite serious in that any further extensive slip will endanger the suction main. The usual method adopted to overcome trouble of this nature would be to drive a line of piling, but as rock is likely near the surface a sufficient depth to make the piling secure could probably not be obtained. Another method would be by placing a stretch of rock-filled cribs on the river bank below which would provide a toe for the slipping to come to rest. Either of these methods would be costly and probably the cheapest and most satisfactory scheme is to closely watch the slipping and if there is danger of the pipe being broken to have this stretch relaid sufficiently far back to be out of the way of any trouble from this cause.

Dear Mr. Waddy:

Your letter of Aug. 25th to hand yesterday with reference to the water intake and the senior boys dormitory first floor (not Junior boys as per your letter), Guy Indian School.

Tell Father Doyen that it would not be to any advantage to extend the present pipe further in the river without first putting the present pipe down deeper, I will explain to you the reason that the inflow pipe is not down deeper in the water.

The inflow pipe coming from the well is down 5'6" below the lowest water level, this level was maintained for a distance of 65' of extra pipe 3" in dia., this pipe was laid at this depth for another two lengths 5' each. Owing to the rock formation in the river the last 22' of pipe had to be raised higher in the river. The contractor could not get the cofferdam tight to excavate the rock with dynamite as the water came thru the rock at the bottom and the pumps he had was not able to keep the water low enough to do the work, we could have added another length of pipe but the water would go into the river at this level the less depth of water we would have at the end of the pipe. You will see by this that to gain an advantage you would have to lower the steel pipe in the river. Supposing you put a fitting on the end of the pipe to extend it out further in the river and to have the end of the length added, deeper in the water you would be working to a better advantage as your pipe would be in deeper and nearer the stream, but it would be no benefit to protect the pipe from freezing in the winter as the supply of water is governed by the part of the pipe nearest the top of the water as it is an inflow pipe not a suction, without lowering the present pipe your best plan would be to put the fitting on, to turn the piece of pipe that you propose to add down in the deep water.

I have explained the particulars to Father Doyen that the trouble will not be now, it may be in the winter from frost unless the pipe is protected, I explained to him that at the late fall of the year as the water over the pipe freezes he will have to cover over the ice for a considerable surface with a good depth of straw or some other covering for a protection, during the very cold weather the river backs up owing to the shallow water in the channels freezing over, when this happens it ensures a protection for the pipe but previous to this taking place it would be wise to protect the pipe, The river will not get low enough to affect the water supply during the spring summer and early fall, the bottom of the pipe is down approximately 4' below the lowest water level taken in Sept. 1926 when the water was very low, that would make the top of the pipe 3'6" below the water at the low water level, you will see that if we had been able to take the pipe thru at the same level as the extra 65' there would be no danger from frost, should the misfortune happen that the pipe would freeze up on them in the river there supply would not be entirely cut off although it would be limited to a reduced quantity, Father
Doyen knows about this, this was the source from which we were able to maintain a water supply last winter while working on the intake, as I have pointed out to you that it be better to connect one sixteenth bend with a piece of pipe 4' long or longer if it is possible with the bend turned downwards, according to the depth of water would determine the length of pipe you should use, I would suggest that you do not use more than 4' or 6' of the pipe or you will have to protect it from being hit from ice or any other debris in the water.

We will prepare a sketch and write the particulars to the Standard Plumbing Co., asking them to supply the required pipe as it is a screwed joint, you can forward the letter and sketch on to them with your requisition, if you decide to have this done.

Personally I do not think you will have the water low enough for Father Doyen to have this done this year, The reason that I am in favour of extending the pipe is to get nearer the stream and I would like to see the pipe longer than four ft., if it could be protected from all danger of being hit by something that would do damage.

With reference to the senior boys dormitory not having toilets wash basins and cubboards,

Kindly look thru the list of requirements that was asked for by the Principle and Sister and you will not find anything asked for this dormitory, The Sister mentioned about requirements in the way of cubboards but did not ask for any, kindly let them know this so I have all particulars of everything they asked for in the way of furnishings on file.

With further reference to this dormitory about the basins and toilets there was no mention of this during the roughing in for the plumbing fixtures, you are aware that we installed hot and cold water basin in the principles room and cold water in the Indians room immediately under this dormitory, that was the time to speak to me about this when we were on the plumbing work, you will understand when we put the extra sinks in the drugroom and drain in the cellar, the toilet in the senior boys dormitory all this was bought in with less expense when done at the proper time, had this been pointed out to me at the proper time I would have taken the matter up.

This dormitory is for the senior boys and I do not see why there should be a run on the toilets during the night that they would require extra toilets, then there is baths and plenty of wash hand basins to spare in the basement, it would be easy to put in a wash basin and connection could be made from the principle room, to install a toilet it would be very expensive compared to having it done at the proper time, The department was not approached for any work to be done in this dormitory, in fact the dept, did not authorize any of the extra work put in by the plumber that I have mentioned, I had this done myself as I could see that theseveral items were necessary and by having them done at the proper time it saved money, I am very much disappointed if the principle and Sister superior say they asked for this additional work to be done in this dormitory if they say so they are wrong, they received all it was possible for me to get for them,

with kind regards,

(Signed) Rod Grant.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent, The Pas, Man.

J.W. if you think it a necessary you can send copies to Father Doyen.

R.G.

Dear Sir;

I beg to report that the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School has asked to be supplied with a long list of unions, valves, nipples, couplings, tees, pipe and pipe taps to amount of $100.00, I got a price placed on the list he submitted.

The explanation with request is that there is no stock of these articles on hand in case of breakdown of water system, and they have had some repairs already to do. I do not like recommending anything further at this time of year, and we have the school pretty well supplied already, but they have a first class mechanic at the school and if he saved only one trip of a plumber from town here he will repay this account over and over, so under the circumstances it appears that the request should be granted.

He also asked me to supply $25.00 of stain, oil, hinges, hooks & eyes etc for completing cupboards. I have sent in so many final requisitions for these cupboards that I will recommend no more, I was handed what I was told the final one last August and sent it to the Department as such. However, if it is considered that this material should be supplied I know it will not be wasted.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Ottawa, April 5th, 1928.

Sir:

Relative to your report for the month of March, last, on the Guy Indian Residential School, it is noted, with reference to the galvanized smoke stack from the boiler to the chimney, that you are having same cleaned and that you are arranging with the blacksmith at the school to carry out the necessary arrangements to make this smoke stack easy of access for cleaning purposes in future.

Relative to the fire escapes, it is noted that the Sisters carry the keys to the doors leading to these escapes. It is considered that some arrangement should be made by the staff to see that the keys are readily accessible in case of fire, so that there would be no delay in reaching the fire escapes.

The Department approves of your suggestion that 4 boxes, with glass fronts, each containing an axe, be installed near the doors, and you may arrange for the purchase and installation of this equipment. No unnecessary expense should be incurred, and when the boxes have been installed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM

Dr. Scott,

With reference to Mr. Wyatt's claim for a balance due on his contract for the erection of the Guy School, I find that an item of $500.00 for extras in connection with the water system was included in the amount of $19062.57 allowed for extras, but when certificate No. 8 was issued, payment of this amount ($500.00) was withheld pending further explanations which were requested on the 14th September 1927. Satisfactory explanation was furnished by Mr. Wyatt and subsequently certificate No. 9 was issued on the 28th October 1927 for the sum of $500.00, which would appear to complete payment in full of Mr. Wyatt's claim. There is an item however inserted in Certificate No. 9 which seems to complicate the matter, and I am inclined to think that this was only inserted by way of explanation for the $500.00 in question. This item reads as follows: "Extra work $500.00 (rock excavation for clearing of channel to divert additional water towards intake water supply system, 100 c.yds. at $5.00 a yard)" and this amount was added to the sum of $111,297.57, thus showing the total amount of Mr. Wyatt's claim to be $111,797.57. I cannot find on the file any correspondence showing that work on this channel to the amount of $500.00 was made twice. I regret that I cannot throw any more light on this subject.

Acting Chief Accountant.
