INTRODUCTORY.

Following the submittal of a report, dated November, 1927, on the water supply of the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, Saskatchewan, by Mr. John Craig, of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service, it was decided to extend the intake pipe twenty feet as was first proposed. It was also decided that the work should be supervised by an engineer from the Winnipeg District Office. Under instructions dated June 16th from Mr. C. H. Attwood, the undersigned was given charge of the laying of this extension to the intake pipe. Three men were engaged for the work which was completed in five days.

In addition to the extension of the intake pipe the instructions covered the following matters:

1 - Examination of intake well.
2 - Examination of bank slide along suction pipe.
3 - Condition of sewerage system.
4 - Examination of water pipe from school to barn.

A general plan of the Guy Indian Residential School showing the extension of the intake pipe, together with photographs are appended.

EXTENSION OF INTAKE PIPE.

Since the existing intake pipe from the eight-inch valve to the outer end was not laid to grade but slopes upward, the extension of the pipe involved a change of direction downward following the bed of the river. A flexible joint at the end of the existing intake would have been the best method of making the connection but one of the required size was not readily available. The method
adopted was to make, in effect, a flexible joint out of two ninety degree elbows connected by a short nipple.

The laying of the pipe comprised the following operations:

1 - Unwatering existing Intake.

A cofferdam extending ten feet out from the shore and enclosing the existing intake was constructed. Difficulty was experienced in pumping out the water on account of water "boiling" up through the mud bottom from crevasses in the rock below.

2 - Connecting Extension.

As soon as the water was lowered sufficiently, the intake screen was removed and a ninety degree elbow screwed on. A short nipple was screwed into the elbow and the second elbow connected to it. Twenty feet of 6-inch steel-pipe, in three sections, were connected to the elbow, and after cleaning, the intake screen was connected on.

3 - Lowering Pipe.

After demolishing the cofferdam the new pipe was propped into an upright position and lowered, by means of a rope over a tripod, into place. The pipe was worked down into a mud bar in the bed of the river but it extends beyond the mud bottom into the current where the river bed is composed of limestone. The end of the pipe, i.e., the intake screen, is held up one and a half feet above the bed of the river by the above mentioned bar.

ADDITIONAL MATTERS.

1 - Examination of Intake Well.

During the construction of the concrete intake well two short lengths of pipe were placed through the wall to drain ground water away from the unset concrete mix. It
was stated that these ground waters were contaminated by manure placed around the outside of the well. The water was tasted but no taste of manure was found. Father Doyen, the principal of the school, was most emphatic that no manure had been placed around the well. The pipes were then plugged with tamarack wood.

2 - Bank Slide along Suction Pipe.

During the construction of the intake a small gully, which crosses the suction pipe, was filled in to make a road. The consequent damming of water at this point was probably the principal cause of the slide for since the placing of a culvert at this place last year no sliding has occurred. Photographs showing the present conditions are appended.

3 - Condition of Sewerage System.

The principal of the school was interviewed regarding the condition of the sewerage system, the cess pools and the outlet examined. Everything was found to be in good working order. A photograph of the outlet is appended.

4 - Water Pipe from School to Barn.

The water pipe which supplies the barn with water is out of commission on account of being frozen last winter. This line is a three-quarter-inch galvanized iron pipe which was laid five feet below the ground surface. The ground through which the pipe runs is a hard-packed sandy soil being part of the boys' playground. It was suggested to the principal that the pipe should be laid nine feet below the surface, boxed and insulated.
CONCLUSIONS.

The intake well and tank were cleaned out and, after a thorough flushing, the water was found to be clear and palatable.

It is noted that since the section of the intake pipe from the eight-inch valve to the double elbow joint was not laid to grade, extra precautions will have to be taken each fall to protect this section from freezing. The principal of the school was advised of this condition.

E. B. Patterson,
Assistant Power Development Engineer.

When I was at the Guy Indian Residential School this summer, the Rev. Principal asked if the Department would reimburse him for expenditure in connection with a house for the school engineer. The Pas, Man.
September 26th 1928.

Dear Sir;-

I have the honor to report that the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School asks for $100.00 lumber for general repairs to the school. He also asks for oak to amount of about $40.00 for making swings for the children and to make a bench for the wood saw.

He also asks for a visit by a dentist to attend to the children, many of whom require the service of a dentist.

He also requests that a toilet and basins be placed in the boys dormitory on the first floor, plan of same is enclosed. This matter was taken up with the Department before, but we could not see where these repairs could be put in without tearing up too much of the building. The mechanic at the school has figured out how this can be done and I have got an estimate from a plumber of $200.00 for the material and work as per list given me by the Principal, this should cover the work, but repairing torn out part of the building will add to the cost. However, the boys in this room should have basins and toilet and I beg to recommend that these be allowed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,

Ottawa.
Ottawa, October 5, 1928.

Sir:

I have your 57-153 of the 26th ultimo, with reference to requests of the Rev. Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School. You may order $140 worth of lumber for the general repairs, for making swings and for benches. You may also arrange for the installation of a toilet and wash basins in the boys' dormitory on the first floor, at an estimated cost of $200. The school should be responsible for repairing the carpenter work after the equipment has been put in position. I am returning the plan which you forwarded with your letter. When the work has been satisfactorily completed, you should forward a properly certified voucher, in duplicate.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the schools of The Pas Agency, which were inspected between September 8th and September 24th, 1928.

**GUY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.**

The school is situated close to the river at Sturgeon Landing, which is a trip up the Saskatchewan of about 24 hours by steamboat from the town of The Pas. The building was erected some two years ago, and is under the supervision of the Roman Catholic Church.

The school building is a very fine structure and modern in every respect. The dormitories are large and bright and were well ventilated. There are three classrooms, which were bright and well furnished. The sewing room, laundry, dining room and playrooms are all bright and airy, and the building throughout was spotlessly clean.

The children enrolled number 108, there being 44 girls and 64 boys. The children were all clean and tidy and appeared quite healthy. The Rev. Father Doyon informed me that during last winter he had a great deal of sickness at the school, but at the present time the children were in good condition. Some children, I understand, have been discharged; the Doctor considered these unfit to stand school life.

The three classrooms were visited and I was delighted with the work. The children spoke out well.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
GUY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

well and appeared to understand their studies. The windows were not open in some of the rooms and I took the opportunity to point out the necessity of keeping plenty of fresh air provided, even in the cold weather.

The school is well supplied with fire equipment, all of which is in good condition. I would, however, point out that the low platform of each fire escape is about 8 ft. from the ground and the children must jump off this on to the ground. This would be very dangerous in case of a fire as the children would no doubt be shoved off by those coming behind and would pile up on the ground beneath the fire escape. An extension reaching to the ground should be provided and this could be hinged on to the platform and raised when not in use.

The barn is situated about 200 ft. south of the school and is in good repair. The chicken house is new and is well built. A machine shed and workshop was under construction and no doubt would be completed within a few days.

The root cellar is built about 100 ft. north of the school. The walls are cement and the roof is covered with poles and dirt, over which is a board roof, covered with roofing paper. Apparently the cellar gives satisfaction as there still remained a few old potatoes and these were quite good.

The school garden consists of about five acres, largely potatoes, although practically all other vegetables were to be found. The garden was well kept.
kept and the vegetables showed excellent growth. No frost had occurred at the time of my inspection.

Five cows are kept at the school, but they were in poor condition and, in fact, appeared to be a poor dairy type. Hay is hard to get as the country is all bush and swamp. The Principal claimed he had 60 loads, but in order to get it he was obliged to go a distance of nearly 20 miles. It is impossible for the five cows to provide milk sufficient for 108 children, as well as a staff of 12 or 14. If more cows cannot be kept, the milk supply could be supplemented by powdered milk. I believe milk added to the children's diet would be of great benefit.

Fish are caught and stored for winter use and, in addition, the children sometimes get moose and beef.

In the summer it is practically impossible to keep meat as there is no ice house. Here, where food must be secured in quantity, an ice house is badly needed.

The Rev. Father pointed out that many of these children come to school a distance of from one to five hundred miles, and when the parents come, as they sometimes do in the winter, there is no building in which they can be accommodated. A small house consisting of two rooms would be ample and would not entail a large expenditure.

I would also point out that the river bank in front of the school is washing away and before long...
a building could be put up at little expense. I should think the school would be glad to do this for their own satisfaction, but a small grant might be made. A log house would be much better than a frame building and $200.00 should supply this if the school would render some assistance.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to forward herewith a report on the various schools in The Pas Agency, which were visited by Mr. Inspector Hamilton during the month of September.

In connection with the Guy Indian Residential School I note what the Inspector says regarding the height of the fire escapes from the ground. This, no doubt, is in accordance with the Department's regulations. I would particularly draw your attention to what the Inspector says regarding the type of cows that are kept at this school, and also the small number that are kept. This, to my mind, is a very important matter. Indians are subject to tuberculosis and unless they get proper and nourishing food, milk in particular, they will fail. As a matter of fact, under the best of conditions they cannot stand confinement as well as White children, so the Department should insist on the proper number of cows being kept at this School. Of course, if there is no way of producing feed for these cows it is another matter, but I have no doubt there is a means of supplying the necessary feed or the Department would never have built a school at this point. These children will be undernourished unless they get milk, especially where fish forms a large part of the diet. You will note the Inspector points out that they have no means of providing storage for meat in the summertime. I do not know that there would be much meat kept there if there are no animals around the place, and if the meat comes in in small quantities in the summer months an ordinary ice house built of logs would meet the requirements. I would also draw your attention to the Inspector's remarks regarding accommodation for Indians visiting the school. This is a small matter. Sir:

I have the honor to enclose report of my visit to The Guy Indian Residential School.

In addition to the formal report, I wish to say that the water intake at this school is working satisfactorily at present, although there was only about two feet of water above the intake and there was some danger of frost on this account, but Father Doyon had a large supply of moss hauled to cover up the place.

The Bootmaker's shop and the Carpenter's shop are being finished at the present time.

The Sewer outlet is exposed as the water has fallen away from that part of the River bank; however, I do not think we will have any trouble from the frost on this account.

There are 350 cords of wood on hand at the school, and the Principal is preparing for next winter stock at the present time.

For recreation the children have been supplied with skates and they certainly enjoy skating around the big lake which is in front of the school.

Dear Sir:-

I have the honor to enclose two letters from the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School.

One letter refers to his solution of the shortage of feed at the school in the future; he asks for a large boat and barge. He was talking to me about this; he would also use the outfit to haul his freight from The Pas. I asked him if he had a boat in sight and he said that Mr. Hayes at Sturgeon Landing wanted to sell his boat and barge for $3,000.00 some time ago but would now accept less. The cost of such an outfit would therefore be about some such figure.

The other letter asks for supply of 125 bags of cement to make railing around the front of the school; he offers to haul 75 of the sax of cement. Further expense would be the supply of gravel and the labor. He states that this was approved by Mr. Ferrier at time of his visit. I will supply the cement if authorized but have nothing on record about it in the office so far.

I have the honor to report that the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School has asked to be supplied with a drying machine for his laundry. He also asks for a 16 H.P. steam boiler to make steam for the dryer and to operate the electric light plant and the pump.

The Principal states that when Mr. Ferrier visited this school last summer these matters were discussed and that favorable consideration was promised by Mr. Ferrier.

A dryer is required at the school, and a steam plant would cut down the operating expenses, as fuel oil as used there now is very expensive.

March 4, 1929.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 16th ultimo with reference to the request from the Principal of the Guy School for a drying machine for his laundry, I beg to say that the Department of late years has been installing a Junior Drying Tumbler, as shown on page 45 of the Catalogue. This machine, although more expensive, has proven much more satisfactory for drying clothes.

With reference to the 16 H.P. steam boiler asked for there will, of course, be required an engine in connection with this boiler if it is their intention to use same for operating the electric lighting plant and pump. Will you please advise me if the Principal would prefer the Junior Drying Tumbler in place of the drying room, also the type of steam boiler and engine required, and if possible an estimate of the cost of the engine and boiler.

I am returning herewith the Catalogue as requested.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Bishop Charlebois has asked me to place the following requests before the Department of Indian Affairs:

For the [signature] School

1.- A steam engine of sufficient power to work the dynamo and the machinery of the laundry. This would replace the gasoline motor which is now in use at the School. It is found that when this motor gets out of order, and new pieces have to be procured for its repair, the house is without light and cannot use the laundry machinery for whole weeks. The motor would be kept at the School and could be used in cases of emergency.

2.- A steam boiler large enough to run the engine and to furnish steam for the drying machine.

It is pointed out that, inasmuch as fuel wood is very cheap in those parts, the expense of running the steam engine would be much less than that of running the gasoline motor.

It would also be a great advantage for the boys at the school to learn how to operate a steam engine.

The installation of the boiler and engine will be done at the expense of the directors of the School.

I have your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to the difficulty of getting the new boiler and steam engine transported to the Guy Indian Residential School at the present time. The Department will rely on you to see that shipment is made as soon as transportation is resumed.

I regret that part of your letter of the 15th ultimo remained unanswered. You may authorize the Rev. Principal to make the most economical arrangements in connection with the overhauling of the gas engine. I note that the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company's expert estimated the cost to be approximately $66.

I have discussed the matter of the electric light battery with the Department Architect, and I believe it advisable to purchase a new one. A new 200 ampere hour, 110 volt, Globe Light Storage Battery may be purchased from the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company, at their quoted price of $766.50, f. o. b. The Pas, Man. When the battery has been supplied, if satisfactory, you should certify to the account, in duplicate, and forward it to Ottawa for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. H. MacKenzie,

Sir:

I beg to report that the water supply at Guy Indian Residential School was practically exhausted two weeks ago and I told the Principal to get some dynamite and deepen the channel from the main stream.

He has had this work underway, I understand, and asks that the Department pay the accounts. I have no idea of what the cost will be but should think that $200.00 would cover it. I beg to recommend that this work be paid for when the accounts are presented, as I may be away from here by that time.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to report that when I came through Sturgeon Landing a short while ago, the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School told me that he was starting school classes for the senior pupils and wished to have twelve large sized single seats supplied, also he asked for one teacher's desk and two chairs and 20 lineal feet of Black Board, three feet high. I beg to recommend that this be supplied.

He also asked that a doorway be cut and a door supplied between the bedroom and sittingroom at the right hand of the main entry of the school. This is the suite used by his Lordship Bishop Charlebois when visiting at the school.

Sir:

I beg to report that there have been numerous forest fires in the vicinity lately and that in coming through Sturgeon Landing, the Guy Indian Residential School was being threatened by fire. As there were no fire rangers in the vicinity, I told the Principal to procure some help and try to put out the fire, which had jumped the river to the Sturgeon Weir Indian Reserve, on which the school is located. I beg to recommend that $50.00 be allowed for this work as the men should be paid for their labor and if an allowance is granted the Principal of the school can supply details and receipts for his expenditures.

Ottawa, September 11, 1929.

Sir:

I have your three letters of the 5th instant, regarding the various matters referred to therein relative to the Guy Indian Residential School.

Your recommendation that the school authorities be reimbursed for the expenditure incurred in the deepening of the channel to obtain an adequate water supply, and also that payment be made for the outlay incurred in the procuring of extra help to assist in putting out the forest fires in the vicinity of the school, has been noted, and the department is today communicating with the Reverend Principal requesting him to forward the necessary vouchers and receipts covering these expenditures. A copy of our communication to the Reverend Principal is enclosed herewith for your information.

Relative to the 12 extra desks required, I have to say that the school desks at present in use are those manufactured by the Canadian Office & School Furniture Co. Ltd., Their western representative is the Western School Supply Ltd., Regina, and you may place your order with this firm for the supplying of twelve (12) Preston ball bearing single school desks, for pupils 15 to 18 years of age, and also for one (1) teacher's sanitary desk, No. 11, and two (2) teacher's arm chairs, No. 23. Please obtain an account, in duplicate, covering the cost of this equipment. When the desks have been received, you should certify the account and forward same to the Department for payment. An order will be placed here to forward through the Government Stationery Office 20' of blackboard material, 3½' wide.

The Department will approve of the expenditure required in having a doorway cut between the bedroom and sitting room on the right hand side of the main entry to the school, also for the supplying of a new door. You may inform the Principal accordingly. A certified account, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost of having this work carried out.

The Pas, Manitoba,
March 3rd, 1930.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report on inspection of the Guy Indian Residential School, Sturgeon Landing, Sask., I found the school in first class shape, due to the efficient management.

There are a few suggestions however which I would make.

The pipes from the furnace in the basement are too near the ceiling, and I would suggest asbestos sheets attached with hangers for attachment to the ceiling. This would require about 50 lin. feet of asbestos with ½ inch iron hangers. The bins for flour, tea, sugar etc., are infected with little white moths and in spite of all the efforts of the Nuns, breed there and spoil all the contents. I suggest these be lined with tin or zinc. The corridors to the height of four feet should be painted white so that they could be washed.

Everything around the out buildings are in splendid shape and reflect credit on the outside staff.

All of which I respectfully submit for your consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa Ontario.
Ottawa, March 8, 1930.

Sir:

I have your two letters of the 3rd instant, relative to the request of the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School for various items of lumber, paint, hardware, etc., and for asbestos covering for the furnace pipes and lining for the flour, tea and sugar bins.

In connection with these requests, I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding the following amounts in the purchase of the various supplies requisitioned for by the Principal:

Lumber $200; Paint $40; Hardware, etc., $60.

The Department will also approve of the supplying of the asbestos sheets with the hangers required in covering the pipes from the furnace which are near the ceiling. Approval is also granted for the purchase of the quantity of tin or zinc required in lining the flour, tea, sugar and other bins in which food supplies are stored at the school.

Before making the purchase, you should consult the Principal as to the type and quantity of the various supplies he requires, but it is to be understood that the above authorized amounts are not to be exceeded. After the purchase has been made, itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the cost. All work is to be performed by the school authorities without expense to the department.

Regarding the painting of the corridors to the height of four feet, I have to say that this work will have to stand for the present.

You might inform the Principal it is expected in future that all materials and labour required in making replacements of a minor nature are to be supplied by the school authorities without expense to the Department.

It is noted that the general conditions around the outbuildings and the school are in good order.

Sir,

The roof over the laundry and engine room is in a very bad shape. The engine room has half a dozen leaks. If we should start on the dynamo or batteries it might cause serious damage.

On further request I wrote my roofing firm who advise as follows:

To supply asphalt roofing material would cost $31.00 for one coat.

Materials for two coats would cost $56.20.

We would have to warm this, put it on hot, afterwards put gravel and sand on, which material we already have on hand.

Cheap help could be hired locally to do this work.

As the leaks are so bad I would strongly advise applying two coats.

Kindly advise what you wish we should do in this matter.

Truly Yours,

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that I visited the Guy School on the 21st instant, by plane, accompanied by the Bishop's Secretary, Rev., M. Lazennesse. There has been so much expense attached to the installation of the boiler and engine, that I thought it right to see how the work was progressing before ordering the last list of material received by Father Lazennesse from the Principal, Father Doyon.

I found that the boiler and engine are in place, and looks like a good job, though all connections are not completed such as the drain from exhaust, which in the old system used to run water all over the floor. Mr. Paterson is using the exhaust steam for heating the drying room and other rooms instead of it going to waste.

He asked for metallic sheeting for the boiler room. I suggested instead asbestos sheets over the piping, same as was put in at the MacKay School, which he agreed would do as well.

The Principal had him plan a Fish Table for the cleaning of fish. Rather a good but elaborate thing, and as it does not impair the efficiency of the plant, I decided not to have it.

In the boiler room, Mr. Paterson was going to build a cement wall 12" thick, 8' high and 15' long, reinforced with 4" steel rods, and a similar wall in the new boiler room 7x5x12, to protect the boilers from wood being thrown in through the shutes. I informed Mr. Paterson that this could be done later if necessary as I did not consider it was work for an expert.

The principal wrote me asking that Mr. Paterson be instructed to repair the pipe in the water tower, which had frozen last winter and burst. I answered his letter, stating that if it would not entail much cost it could be done, otherwise he must submit the estimated cost for your approval. He merely answered that it would not cost much and that Mr. Paterson had started on the job.

In my absence at Treaty he ordered lumber for making another casing and sawdust for filling in between, so as the material is on the ground, I thought it as well to have it done and save further trouble in the winter or in case of fire.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM REV. J. A. LAJEUNESSE, O.M.I., Ottawa University, dated Sept. 10, 1930.

Original on 132-7-9.

Re: Ice house and list of Requisitions:

The Department had decided last year to build an ice house for the Guy School, and the building was to be put up this summer. Nothing has been done as yet. In the list of requisitions which we presented to the Department last spring, and which was sent back to our agent for approval, many articles were crossed out by the agent which we need badly and which, I am sure, the Department would have been disposed to grant us. It seems that the agent is over-zealous in these matters. Besides, none of the things that were asked for and approved by the agent have been received so far.
Ottawa, September 12, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

Father Lajeunesse has brought to the Department's attention your request for an exchange of land at the Guy Indian Residential School. I may say that this was granted two years ago, and I cannot do better than enclose a copy of the official letter to His Lordship Bishop Charlebois.

Concerning a road from Sturgeon Landing to the Flin-Flon Railway, a distance of 16 miles, I may say that the Department would be favourably disposed to provide some assistance next year. It will be necessary to know, however, what the work will cost and what proportion would be expected from us.

A note is being taken for next year's Estimates in connection with the ice house. You might let me know, in a separate letter, whether the school would be satisfied with an ordinary ice house or whether you are hoping to secure a freezer. If a building equipped for freezing fish and meat is really needed, the Department will expect the church authorities to bear a portion of the cost. The ordinary ice house and cold storage that the Department generally builds at Indian residential schools costs approximately $1500. The plans that Bishop Charlebois had some time ago call for a building which would cost approximately $5,000.

I trust that the articles which have been allowed by the Department on recent requisitions have now been purchased and have reached the school.

Enclosed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. H. Doyon, O. M. I.,
Principal,
Guy Indian Res. School,
Sturgeon Landing, SASK.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSHARD,

With reference to your memorandum of the 16th instant, concerning improvements to the heating plant at the Guy Indian Residential School, I may say that this institution is 135 miles by water from The Pas, Man. The School is located in Saskatchewan and is really not in the agency of Mr. Tweedell, our representative at The Pas. The reason Mr. Tweedell is asked to assume some responsibility is that all transportation to the school is via The Pas.

In the case of remote Indian residential schools, of necessity, the Department must deal direct, in part, with the school principal or the church authority that is directly responsible for the management. With particular reference to improvements at The Guy School, instructions are sometimes given to Mr. Indian Agent Tweedell and sometimes to the Roman Catholic Bishop, the Right Reverend O. Charlebois, O.M.I., who is also at The Pas.

A Mr. Patterson, an engineer of the Fairbanks-Morse Company, of Winnipeg, has been at the school in connection with the installation of a steam engine, a boiler, laundry machinery, an electric battery and necessary fittings which were purchased from the Company. Bishop Charlebois was given the authority direct from Ottawa to engage the company's engineer. I wanted the installation of the mechanical plant to be done by an expert and to be entirely satisfactory to the church authorities. For this service, the engineer is to receive $25 per day. His accounts for his services have yet reached the Department; but, when they are before us, they will be scrutinized with the usual care.

The accounts for fittings and other materials used in connection with the installation of the new equipment were certified by the Reverend Father M. Lajeunesse, who is Bishop Charlebois' business executive. Indian Agent Tweedell's attitude in the matter has been entirely correct. He could not certify to some of the accounts in connection with Mr. Patterson's services and the improvements themselves, because the authority was not directed to him and he was not being held responsible for the work.

Regarding the necessity for the improvements, I may say that they were recommended by our own Architect. Some additional repairs to mechanical plant have been authorized since Mr. Patterson arrived at the school, following the recommendation of the Indian Agent. If the School Principal has had any further work done, of course, he will have to meet the costs.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

September 17, 1930

Mr. Waddell,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Dear Sir:

I am giving you a rough time sheet of work done at Guy Indian School installing new machinery. The work actually started on June 30th and finished August 31st. Blue prints will be forwarded on to you from Winnipeg as soon as printed, with any additional information you may require.

Regarding the machinery.

There is one locomotive return tube type of boiler installed for supplying a 16 horsepower Climax Engine with steam. 125 lb. pressure.

Also a complete new set of Globelite Batteries, And one steam dryer for the laundry.

Taking the boiler first.

There is one Duplex steam pump for supplying water to the boiler. Water can be taken by the pump from:
(1) The heating return mains
(2) The hot water tank
(3) Cold water from the water tower.

There are also two steam Penberthy injectors, either one of which can be used to supply water to the boiler; the water being drawn from a separate tank in boiler room.

A cold water supply is also directly coupled up to the boiler from the building water main; this can be used when the steam pressure is below 20 pounds.

So there are five different ways of supplying water to the boiler:
(1) By Steam Pump
(2) By One Injector
(3) By a Second Injector
(4) By cold water direct from water system when pressure is below 20 pounds.
(5) By hot water direct from hot water storage tank when pressure is below 20 pounds.
Mr. Waddell - 2.

Taking the 16 HP Steam "Climax" Engine next.

It is capable of running all the following at the same time:

(1) Charging the batteries and supplying the building with light.
(2) Pumping Water
(3) Running laundry machinery
(4) Running baking machine.

The exhaust piping from the engine has been installed to:

(1) Heat the radiators in the water tower.
(2) Heat the radiators in the laundry steam dryer.
(3) Heat the hot water
(4) Supply the building with heat.

By this method, no heat is wasted in the exhaust steam, so making the plant a most economical one.

The steam dryer in the laundry is heated with exhaust steam from the engine. There is also a line steam connection from the high pressure steam pipe that can be used when the engine is not running.

I remain,

Yours truly,

O. Pettersson,
Erector for Fairbanks-Morse.
MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, September 16, 1930.

Dr. Scott,

The attention of the Minister has been drawn to certain work in connection with the heating plant now under way at the Guy Indian School in northern Manitoba. It has been stated that the changes are more extensive than was reported as necessary by the Agent on the Reserve; that the man now employed on the work is from Winnipeg and is being paid at the rate of $12.00 per day; that the Agent refused to certify to the accounts, and that the accounts have been paid upon the certification of an outside party.

Would you please let the Minister have a report dealing fully with the attitude of the Agent in the matter, the employment of the help from Winnipeg, and also as to the name of the party who has been certifying to the accounts and what connection he has with the Department.

Private Secretary.
September 19, 1930.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

With reference to your memorandum of the 16th instant, concerning improvements to the heating plant at the Guy Indian Residential School, I may say that this institution is 135 miles by water from The Pas, Man. The School is located in Saskatchewan and is really not in the agency of Mr. Tweedell, our representative at The Pas. The reason Mr. Tweedell is asked to assume some responsibility is that all transportation to the school is via The Pas.

In the case of remote Indian residential schools, of necessity, the Department must deal direct, in part, with the school principal or the church authority that is directly responsible for the management. With particular reference to improvements at The Guy School, instructions are sometimes given to Mr. Indian Agent Tweedell and sometimes to the Roman Catholic Bishop, the Right Reverend O. Charlebois, C.M.I., who is also at The Pas.

A Mr. Patterson, an engineer of the Fairbanks-Morse Company, of Winnipeg, has been at the school in connection with the installation of a steam engine, a boiler, laundry machinery, an electric battery and necessary fittings which were purchased from the Company. Bishop Charlebois was given the authority direct from Ottawa to engage the Company's engineer. I wanted the installation of the mechanical plant to be done by an expert and to be entirely satisfactory to the church authorities. For this service, the engineer is to receive $12 per day. No accounts for his services have yet reached the Department; but, when they are before us, they will be scrutinized with the usual care.

The accounts for fittings and other materials used in connection with the installation of the new equipment were certified by the Reverend Father M. Lajeunesse, who is Bishop Charlebois' business executive. Indian Agent Tweedell's attitude in the matter has been entirely correct. He could not certify to some of the accounts in connection with Mr. Patterson's services and the improvements themselves, because the authority was not directed to him and he was not being held responsible for the work.

Regarding the necessity for the improvements, I may say that they were recommended by our own Architect. Some additional repairs to mechanical plant have been authorized since Mr. Patterson arrived at the school, following the recommendation of the Indian Agent. If the School Principal has had any further work done, of course, he will have to meet the costs.

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Att. Mr. [signature]

Dear Sir,

Please find enclosed the last accounts in regard with the installation of Boiler, Steam Engine, Dryer, Batteries, repairing of Water Tower etc at The Guy Indian Residential School.

The expenses are somewhat higher than it was expected, notwithstanding my constant efforts to keep them down. I do not want to boast about my work but I think you would like to know what I have done in the interest of The Department.

First of all, in July 1929, I have obtained from The Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co. Ltd., absolutely free of charge, the services of an expert who went to Sturgeon-Landing to take all the measurements and made out blue print of the work to be done. It was calculated that both expenses and labor amounted to $152.20.

Regarding the time, the Engineer, Mr. Petterson spent on the job, there was one whole week, from September 1st to 8th, inclusive, for which no charge was made. In addition to this, as I represented that we should not be charged for the sundays, though they were practically spent in checking up material, making orders, keeping time etc... I have been granted $58.00 credit note for this.

I have also obtained from the Beaver Lumber Co. Ltd., $60 discount on the lumber though their account is due since three months. At my request, the Rev. Father Principal has also passed $58.00 credit note for the work done by his team and charged for on the Return of Labour.

Finely, with the approbation of His Lordship Bishop Charlebois, I have also discarded an account for $93.00 presented by Rev. Father Doyon for the board of Mr. Petterson for the 62 days he was at the School.

You will find enclosed a blue print and a complete report of the work done, showing the time spent on each job, as well as the number of hours spent by additional labor which was deemed necessary.

Hoping that you will find this satisfactory and thank you for your courtesy in this matter,

I remain, Yours very truly,

[signature]

MEMO

Letter from Father Doyon, Principal of the Gulk School, Sturgeon Landing.

The wagon road between Sturgeon Landing and the Flin-Flon railway is almost completed. It will be used this coming winter. Its cost will be about $1,500.00. The Provincial Government has promised to pay a part of the expense, and it is expected that the Department of Indian Affairs will pay at least a part of the balance.

Re Refrigerating Plant -

The plans of the refrigerating plant have been received, and Father Doyon would undertake to build it for the sum of $5,000.00.

Re Mowing Machine and Rake -

The mowing machine and the rake which were furnished to the School some years ago are now out of order. New ones will be needed for the coming year.

Presented by J.A. Lajeunesse, O.M.I.
Ottawa, December 6, 1930.

Reverend Sir,

Reverend Father Lajeunesse has brought to the Department's attention your request for next year's estimates. I have noted that you beg the Department to give a grant toward the cost of the road from Sturgeon Landing to the railway; and that you would like a refrigerating plant. I may say that I am not hopeful that the refrigerator can be supplied next year as our funds are and will be needed for really urgent improvements.

With reference to replacing the mower and the hay rake I may say that this will have to be done from the per capita or other school earnings. When the Department builds a residential school a full complement of agricultural implements and livestock is supplied but all replacements have to be made by the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

The Rev. Father N. Doyon, Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, Sask., called here with a Requisition for repairs, which I inclose for your approval.

Re the first item. 22' x 1 11/16 Shaft. This shaft has been damaged slightly, through contact with an iron rod, which in some way was out of place. The shaft is 1 11/16" in diameter, and the weight of the rod coming in contact with the shaft has worn or cut a slight groove in the shaft, about 1/16" deep. Father Doyon fears it might break. Not being quite satisfied that the shaft might break, I called upon Mr. Williams, The Pas Superint. of Utilities, and he advises me there is no necessity for a new shaft, but in case of a break we should purchase and have on hand a Ribbed Compression Coupling from the Fairbank Morse Coy., for 1 11/16" shaft, catalog No. 2377, costing in the neighborhood of $7.60. By putting this coupling on the same shaft would be O.K.

The 1100 ft. of wire is for connecting the lights to the workshop and barn.

The items Connecting Rod and Piston, complete, I have deleted till I receive further information as to immediate necessity. I presume that these are meant to be spare parts.

Gentlemen:

The Department has received a report on the condition of the boiler installed by your Company at the Guy Indian Residential School and which shows a very serious defect in the collar around the dome. The Principal, in his report, states that this boiler came very near exploding and that there is a hole, which he considers is the result of faulty construction, at the place mentioned. The engineer at the school states that, after a thorough examination, the place where this hole occurred was found to have been patched or repaired and the work very badly done at that. He states the collar around the dome is riveted with two rows of rivets and that the hole is between these two rows of rivets. Our Agent at The Pas states that this boiler was installed some three months ago by your firm and results show defective workmanship or material.

It is considered that your firm should undertake the necessary repairs, sending an expert to do the work, and without cost to the Department or the school authorities. I shall be pleased if you will give this matter your prompt attention, as it is necessary that these repairs be carried out as soon as possible. The Department will be pleased to hear from you as to what action you are prepared to take regarding the carrying out of the repairs required. Dear Sirs;

Attention - Mr. F. W. Miller.

Answering your letter of June 16th, in connection with our letter of June 17th, re boiler at the Guy Indian School, Sturgeon Landing.

Since receiving your letter I have had a personal interview with Mr. H. A. Stewart, Chief Inspector of Boilers for Manitoba, and he informs me that the boiler on which trouble developed may not be required until fall, as the scholars will be at the homes for the summer, and the boiler may not be required until school is reopened. Mr. Stewart expects to leave for Churchill in a couple of weeks, and would make a personal inspection of this boiler along with his local inspection of that district, if it is in Manitoba. He is in doubt however, as to whether Sturgeon Landing is in Manitoba, as it is near the Saskatchewan border. If it is in Saskatchewan, of course, he would have no jurisdiction, and we would have to make our own inspection.

The C.W.R. has volunteered to get the boat sailings from The Pas for us, and owing to the lack of this information now, we will be unable to leave by train tomorrow, as gas and oxygen will have to be forwarded and should be on the ground before we arrive there.

In the meantime, while I could carry out instructions given in yours of June 16th, re details of the trip, I think it would be well to wait in any event until we get some idea as to sailing dates, so that very little time would be lost making connection between the Pas and Sturgeon Landing.

Hoping you may be able to advise us as to the Provincial location of Sturgeon Landing, we are -

Yours very truly,

VULCAN IRON WORKS LIMITED.

GUY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (R.C.)

I was delighted with the improvements made at this school since my last visit. The yards have been well planned, levelled, and proper swings and teeters erected for the children. More land has been cleared and they now have two good sized gardens. The barn yard has been cleared of stumps and rocks, and new fences built and proper roads and driveways arranged.

The school I found to be spotlessly clean throughout, and the surplus clothes and bedding all neatly arranged.
GUY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (R.C.) (CONT'D.)

arranged in various closets.

The sewing room is well equipped, and I found a goodly supply of clothes, both for boys and girls, neatly stored away. The clothes are all made by the senior girls assisted by the Sisters in charge, and the work is all well done.

The laundry is well arranged and the machinery appeared in good repair. The metallic ceiling is badly rusted from the steam and dampness, and needs painting.

The kitchen work is carried on by the girls, supervised by a Sister, and all food is well prepared and nicely served. This year over 300 jars of wild fruit and rhubarb were preserved, as well as over 250 jars of peas, beans, tomatoes, corn, and squash, all of which had been grown in their own garden. This Sister also supervised the making of 18 large barrels of sauer-kraut.

The dormitories were clean, the beds neatly made, and the rooms all well aired and bright.

The fire escapes are all in good condition, and none of the doors leading to them are locked. An alarm bell is fixed on each door, which rings the moment it is opened so that it is impossible for anyone to open the door without an alarm being given. Fire drill is observed regularly, and a night man kept on duty.

The playrooms were tidy and well aired. All toilets I found in good working order and clean. Excellent care is given to all machinery, all of which appeared to be in perfect working order.

Sir:

With reference to your telegram of today's date, regarding the burnt out generator at the Guy Indian Residential School, The Pas Agency, I could not obtain one of the type required in Regina, and could receive no assurance that one could be secured in Winnipeg. In view of this, and also in view of the fact that the generator is crated and at the station in The Pas, I have arranged to have it shipped to Winnipeg to-night by express, and am sending special instructions through a firm here to have the generator repaired as a rush order. I am hoping I shall be able to have this wound and repaired within two days after its arrival, which should be Wednesday morning, and will probably have it returned to the school and the current on by next Saturday or Monday at the latest.

I am told this procedure will be quicker than if a new generator were purchased as, in all probability, a man would have to go up to The Pas to take measurements, etc. I trust this action will meet with your approval.

In the meantime, the school will have to carry on for three or four days with coal oil.

A new generator would probably cost over $600.00, and I did not feel that it would be wise to spend this amount at this time.

Dear Sir:

Last week, M.A.G. Hamilton, Inspector from Winnipeg, paid a visit to our school. After a thorough inspection of the school and of the buildings, Mr. Hamilton suggested what is most necessary to me to ask the Department for at the present time. May I call your attention on the following items.

1. Mr. Hamilton noticed that the school needs painting outside and inside as well, and also the other buildings. He suggested that the Department should supply the school with paint.

2. The school would also benefit of a binder if the Department would buy one. We grow enough oats now to make good use of it.

3. I spoke to Mr. Hamilton of an idea that runs across my mind for quite a while. He approved of it and suggested that I refer the case over to the Department. Here is the idea: I want a sawmill. It can be operated at a low cost and both the Department and the school can have a great benefit out of it. Every year, since the opening of the school, an average of $200 is spent on lumber and the Department did not give any financial help to that effect for the last four years. Here the timber is plentiful and the quality of the lumber would satisfy the ordinary requirements. Every year a few thousand feet of lumber can be cut for the general purpose of the school. A good second-hand transportable sawmill can be bought at a very reasonable price and I kindly ask the Department to share with me the burden of the purchase. Let the Department give me $200, and I supply the balance of the purchase price, and I finance the operation and the upkeep of the sawmill.

4. The school has been providing with 8 fire pumps, but four should be replaced at once because they are out of order.

In the course of next week, you will very likely receive Mr. Hamilton's report; I hope that it will be very satisfactory.

I hope that the Department will take into serious consideration the above-mentioned necessities which the school is facing at the present time and I sincerely wish that
they all come to their fullest realization.

Mr. Hamilton, while visiting up here, mentioned that very likely a Member of the Department Of Indians will come and pay a visit to Sturgeon Landing during the summer months. I anticipate the pleasure of welcoming the honorable Member. He will then convince himself of the necessities which the school has been asking for.

I remain,

Truly Yours,

[Signature]

Rev. Napoleon Boyce, O.M.I.

Sir:

I have just returned from an inspection trip to the Guy R.C. Indian Residential School, The Pas Agency, and beg to submit the following report.

There are 87 children in attendance, which are arranged in three classrooms, as follows.

The junior room is in charge of Sister of Precious Blood and there are 13 pupils in Grade I and 21 pupils in Grade II.

The intermediate room is in charge of Sister St. Eusele, with 13 in Grade III and 9 in Grade IV.

Sister St. Philip de Marie is in charge of the senior grades with 14 in Grade V, 15 in Grade VI, and 2 in Grade VII.

I spent some little time in all the rooms and was pleased with the work. The children, without exception, can be heard to read from any part of the classroom. They read with expression and understanding.

The arithmetic, spelling, and oral work was good. I examined their scribblers and work books, which I found to be neat and the work well set out.

I am glad to report that splendid progress is being made in all classrooms; the Sisters in charge speak good English and, I believe, are rendering their best services.

The children were all well dressed, clean, and neat in appearance. Their hair was well kept and combed.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
The discipline is excellent, and yet there is freedom and understanding, which makes the work very pleasant.

The children appeared in good health, except for two boys who are confined to bed suffering from T.B. They are isolated from the other pupils and receive the best of care and attention.

The fire equipment is in good condition, except the fire hose. These are cracked in places where they are folded back and forth on the racks. Six new hose should be provided. The dormitory doors are never locked and I found the fire escapes in good condition and free from snow. Electric bells ring if the doors are opened. A night watchman is on duty, but this is never satisfactory unless the school is provided with a punch clock and stations placed throughout the building. I would strongly recommend that a clock be provided. This is a frame building and every precaution should be taken to prevent fire. The small fire extinguishers are in good condition, but the large ones have not been refilled during the past year. I understand the solution should be renewed yearly.

The dormitories were all well aired, the beds neatly made and clean. The mattresses are homemade. I understand the Department supplied the ticking. These mattresses are almost on a par with those purchased, being filled with cotton and wool. I think the Sisters deserve great credit for this work.

The sewing room is in charge of a Sister and the girls are taught plain sewing. I saw large quantities
quantities of clothing made by the girls, and the work was neat and well done. They make all their own dresses and underclothing, also shirts, pants, coats, and underclothing for the boys. The girls also receive a splendid training in cooking and laundry work. In summer all the children do some work in the garden.

The building was clean throughout, and excellent care has been taken of the school and equipment. It was erected in 1926 and no interior decorating has since been done. The white walls need paint, especially in the kitchen and halls. I see that in the 1933-34 Estimates $600.00 was asked for repairs. If any portion of this is available, I would like permission to buy some paint. The Reverend Principal will see that same is applied without cost to the Department. The Sisters are anxious that some cleaning be done and I trust that a small expenditure may be incurred. A hundred dollars would supply a fair amount and would greatly encourage the staff in their work. The exterior of the school is greatly showing the need of paint.

The main barn is about 30 ft. by 40 ft. and accommodates both the horses and cattle. At present they have 4 horses and 10 cows beside a number of young stock. The Reverend Principal feels he could do better by killing the present stock for beef and purchasing 4 or 5 registered cows with some record of production. Feed is hard to secure in this country and no doubt a few cattle of a higher class would be more profitable. The barn is badly in need of paint, most of it having peeled off.

The chicken house is in good repair. The poultry is well cared for, and fresh eggs were gathered daily.
daily, although the weather registered 20 to 35 below zero.

There are four large root cellars; funds for one were provided by the Department, but the other three were erected at the expense of the school authorities. These cellars, even yet, have a bountiful supply of potatoes, carrots, beets, cabbage, turnips, and sugar beets. In fact, although this school is far north, it has perhaps the largest supply of vegetables, with the exception of Brandon, of any school I visited this past year. The children have abundance of food, both vegetables and meat. The menu is as follows:

**Breakfast** - Fish with rice or potatoes; bread and lard. Tea with milk and sugar.

**Dinner** - Soup; meat with beans or macaroni, or fish and potatoes. Once a week, dessert - syrup, prunes, dried apples with doughnuts or cake. Tea with milk & sugar. All the bread they desire.

**Luncheon** - Raw carrots; bread cakes or bannock.

**Supper** - Fish and porridge; bread with lard; tea with milk & sugar.

The children have all the food they wish, and certainly appear well fed.

In the warehouse was stored about 4,000 frozen whitefish and trout, and nearly 3,000 lbs. of beef was packed away in ice. The other storehouse was filled to capacity with flour, oatmeal, sugar, rice, and all the other supplies necessary to do until December of this year. All freight now goes over the Hudson Bay railway to Atik and is freighted in some 20 miles during the winter.

The Reverend Principal has cleared a quantity of land and has made a wonderful improvement in the grounds surrounding the school. Last year, he grew approximately
approximately 15 acres of oats and hopes to increase this to at least 25 or 30 acres. He requested that a 6 ft. binder be supplied to assist in harvesting. The sheaves could then be stored under cover and no waste would occur. We have very little outlay in machinery at this point and, if possible, I would like to have the binder supplied.

The garden certainly must have been an object lesson to all who visited the school. In addition to the supply of roots stored, the Sisters have a large quantity of home canned peas, beans, tomatoes (ripe), corn on the cob, as well as all kinds of mixed pickles. This school is doing excellent work and is worthy of any consideration which the Department can give.

The Principal, Rev. Father Doyon, pointed out the need for lumber, both for repair work and for the erection of outbuildings. He stated that each year the expense in this connection reached $200.00, and felt that it would be to the advantage of all if a sawmill could be provided. He stated if the Department would supply $200.00, he would raise the balance required and pay all other costs. I am quite sure a suitable outfit would cost at least $500.00.

I feel the Reverend Principal has presented a reasonable proposition, and as the school would reap the benefit, in that all the rough lumber necessary could be provided, I would recommend that the Department grant assistance to the extent of $200.00.

It is perhaps unfortunate that a school of such high standard is so situated that few white people are privileged to see it. Certainly it is a credit, both to the Department and the church, and is undoubtedly doing excellent
excellent work in the classroom as well as outside. The children receive a thorough training - the boys, in gardening, care of stock, shoemaking, and carpentering; the girls, in cooking, sewing, laundry work, and also in gardening. The discipline is excellent and I am sure the pupils leave the school much better fitted to cope with whatever conditions they may be obliged to face.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that it was found necessary to send the dynamo of the Guy Indian Residential School to the Electric Equipment Limited, Regina, Sask., for repairs.

Father Doyon stated the armature had to be tested, also it was not straight on the shaft. The commutators were grounded between the bars, and it was sent to the same firm as repaired it once before, as these repairs could not be done here.

The school, meantime, are carrying on with oil lamps, hence the rush to have this dynamo repaired.

I trust this will meet with your approval.

Dear Sir,

I have a letter from the Rev. N. Doyon, O.M.I., the Principal of Guy Indian Residential School, in which he asks that his steam boiler be inspected.

The Department of Public Works, Regina, state that they do not make regular inspections of boilers in such remote places, but if the Department of Indian Affairs, will pay all the expenses of the inspector from Hudson Bay Junction and the school and return, they will send an inspector up on a special trip. They further state that the trip will take the better part of a week.

This boiler has been in the school, I believe, for about ten years and has never been inspected by a competent person. I think it desirable that this boiler be inspected periodically so that we can be sure it is quite safe.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, January 16, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, relative to the request of the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School to have the steam boiler inspected.

In reply I have to say the Department regrets there will be no funds available during the present fiscal year to pay the cost of an inspector of the Provincial Department of Public Works, Regina, from Hudson Bay Junction to the school and return. While it is, no doubt, desirable that an inspection be made, could not the school authorities, themselves, pay the cost of the inspection? It is hoped that the school authorities have a competent engineer in charge of the boiler and that every care is taken in its management and operation.

For your information, I may add that a request has also been received from the Principal, to be supplied with certain farm machinery and paint for the exterior of the school building, shop and henhouse, and a quantity of piping, couplings, etc., for the steam boilers. You were authorized, in official letter of the third ultimo, to purchase 6 pieces of 2", extra strong, galvanized iron piping for the hot water boiler. I would request that you arrange to have this supplied and the accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, forwarded for payment before the end of the present fiscal year, viz.: March 31st, next.

Regarding the other equipment asked for by the Principal, he is being informed that, until our Estimates are passed by Parliament at its next session, we will be unable to state what funds, if any, are available during the coming fiscal year to supply equipment for this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

I have your 205-11A R.C. of the 19th instant, regarding the request of the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School, to be supplied with a small binder and also to have certain repairs carried out.

In this connection I have to inform you that there is an item, to the amount of $500.00 in our Estimates for the current fiscal year for painting and miscellaneous repairs at this school. Accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the cement, should be forwarded for payment. After payment has been made for the cost of installing another roof over the room in which the pressure boiler is installed and the cement supplied, the Department will approve of the balance of $500.00 available being utilized in the purchase of paint, oils, etc., in the painting required to the exterior of the school building. Dear Sir,

When I was at the Guy Indian Residential School recently, the Principal drew to my attention to condition of the boiler used for heating the water required for the School. This boiler is in very bad condition. In fact it is in a dangerous condition, as it is extremely thin and there are over thirty patches in it.

The boiler is heated through pipes running through the furnace in winter and by a jacket heater in summer.

I wrote to Inspector Hamilton and reported the matter to him and asked him to find out in Winnipeg what the cost of a new boiler would be. One with black coil pipes would cost $330.00 and one with brass coil pipes would cost $383.00. There would probably be additional cost for installation as there would be other material required connecting it up. The staff could do the actual work of installing it. I think $20.00 in addition to the cost of the boiler would cover everything.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Mr. Agent Lovell, The Pas, Man., telegraphs that the batteries in connection with the electric light system at the Guy Indian Residential School, Sturgeon Landing, Sask., (Electoral District of Melfort) are completely worn out and that the school is without light, other than candles and lamps.

The present batteries were supplied this school in October, 1935, and were obtained from the Fairbanks-Morse Company, Limited, Winnipeg, at a cost of $766.00, f. o. b. The Pas. A 200 amp. hour, 56 cell, 110 volt battery is required. The best available source of supply is Winnipeg.

I beg to recommend that approval be granted to incur the expenditure and that Mr. Inspector Hamilton, Winnipeg, arrange for the purchase and shipment of the batteries to the school. I shall be pleased to have the names of the firms from whom quotations should be received, either in Winnipeg or The Pas.

Funds to cover the cost of new batteries for this school are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education. As the matter is urgent, I should be pleased to have your early direction.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing herewith Requisition for supplies for Guy Indian Residential School, which I have received from the Rev. Father N. Doyon and also prices for these articles, which I have got from Winnipeg.

The Principal has pointed out that the saw mill would be useful for making lumber for the school and also for lumber for ex-pupils residing around the school.

At the present time I do not see why the school requires a great deal of lumber. They have, as far as I know, all the buildings they require. As far as supplying ex-pupils who reside in the vicinity of the school with lumber, I do not approve of ex-pupils when they leave school settling near the school. There is nothing for them to do there and the fur is very scarce in that vicinity. A few of them reside near the school now and they are constantly asking for relief. I can therefore see no immediate need for this saw mill and cannot recommend it.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I was asked to go to Guy Indian Residential School this week as they had had an accident with their steam engine. There had apparently been an explosion and it had completely wrecked the engine.

This engine is the power they use for light, pumping water and all other power required around the buildings. They are using a small auxiliary gas engine at present, but it has not sufficient power and in case of fire it would be practically useless.

I have made enquiries from the Fairbanks Morse Co. of Winnipeg and they tell me they will supply a fifteen horse Vertical Automatic Steam Engine with pulley for $675.00 F.O.B. Winnipeg.

This engine appears to be essential for the efficient running of the school and also for safety in case of fire and I therefore recommend that it be purchased and sent to the Guy Indian Residential School, as soon as possible. They inform me they will be able to install it themselves.

I could not determine what was the cause of the damage to the engine and none of the staff could give any reason.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Guy Indian Residential School

I have just been advised by the Indian Agent that as a result of an explosion the steam engine at the above-mentioned school has been completely wrecked. This engine is the power used for lighting, pumping water and all other power purposes around the school. At the present time they are using a small auxiliary gas engine but it has not sufficient power. In the case of fire it would be practically useless.

Director.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 132-7-5, dated Oct. 26th with regard to request of the Principal of Guy Indian Residential School for additional fire escapes.

I visited the School recently and I would say that additional fire escapes are necessary. At the present time they have two fire escapes of the steel stairs and platform style. They are both at the back of the building and extend from the ground to the attic. I think under stress, especially in winter time when they were slippery with ice, it might be difficult to get the children out with any great speed.

I suggest a frame structure be erected on the left side of the building 6 by 8 feet in which be placed a pole fire escape from the first floor to the second story and from the second story to the attic. They would come down on the porch and a slide could be erected from there to the ground. It would be necessary to make doors in the building to provide outlets to the escape.

I also suggest that similar pole escape be provided on the other end of the building. It would not be necessary to build a structure on this end of the building, except from the 2nd storey to the attic as the rest of the way it would come through the verandah.

I got an estimate from Harrison and Leneville, The Pas on this job. They estimate it would cost $1325.00. This firm is the only one doing this kind of work on the preferred list. I do not know how they arrived at their figures, but I think the amount is extraordinarily large.

Your obedient servant,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant with reference to the request of the Principal of the Guy residential school for a new generator for the school power plant.

In this connection I would refer you to my letter of the 19th instant regarding the amount provided in the current year's appropriation for new equipment, repairs and improvements at the Guy school. A decision regarding the new generator cannot be made until you reply to that letter.

Apparently the generator at present in use was manufactured in the United States. In the event of the Department deciding to supply a generator we would prefer ordering one manufactured either in England or Canada. Dear Sir:

Find enclosed informations required by your purchasing agent for generator requested at our school.

I am also including my account for $74.32 for beltin which account has been returned to me last week by our indian agent. I had to wait three months to get a new engine. At last came the vertical engine, new type which requires only one belt but doubled in thickness. That is why I purchase it at the first opportunity being sure that the Dept.would not refuse to give a belt with the new engine. However, Mr Hoey, if you find out that it is impossible to reimburse it, you have only to throw it away.

Can I ask you, Mr Hoey, how much contribution will the Dept.give to Guy School for the transportation of children during summer vacation?. Water is so low now, it is getting quite impossible to carry children by canoe as in previous years. We find many more advantages in carrying them by planes. We obtained that privilege to double the number of children in plains, so the cost of transportation will be lessened. However the gross total cost charged by the Wings Co, who has the contract, will be $1106.00 for return trip. Would you, please, let me know what will be your contribution, if any.

During May I received from Mr W.R. Leslie, Superintendent of the D.Experimental Farm at Morden, some 200 seedlings for my garden, for which I am very grateful to you.

Very few sick children during the year, no death. Very good work performed by the sisters and other members of the staff. Children will be glad to see their parents between the 15 and 20 of June, but also will be very pleased to come back in August.

Details and specifications necessary for the rebuilding of the water tank at Guy School.

WOODEN TANK:

The tank to be circular having an inside diameter of 10 feet on a minimum height of 16 feet.

The beams on top of the posts supporting the tank floor to be of 10 x 12 dressed timber, extending to the outer edges of the tank house, and fastened to the end of each post with strap irons 5" x 3/8" bolted together with ¼" bolts.

The joists supporting the floor to be formed of 4" x 12" all in one piece and spaced at 16" centres. The joists outside of the water tank may be formed of 2" x 12". Bracing 2" x _ shall be placed between these joists for the nailing of the floor around the tank house.

The tank to be built with staves 3" x 6" wide made of No1 California red wood properly bevelled and matched as per detail.

The floor to be built of 3" x 6" planks, dressed on the four sides well matched and grooved to receive the staves. The staves to be secured together and in place with round iron hoops 7/8"x ¾" diameter well threaded and provided with metal turbuckles and double nuts.

The first five hoops at the bottom to be 7/8" diameter, the remainder to be ¾". All metal used in the construction of the tank to be previously painted with two coats of graphite paint.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter 132-7-5, dated the 3rd instant, I am enclosing herewith Requisition for Supplies covering material for a water tank for Guy Indian Residential School.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 132-7-5, dated the 12th instant, in connection with erection of water tank at Guy School.

It was my intention to employ Indians to do this work, under the supervision of one of the men employed by the School. The man I had in mind is an experienced carpenter, who would work with and direct the Indians. It would be necessary to pay him, as someone else would have to be engaged by the School to do his regular work while he was working on the tank. He has promised to work for 50 cents per hour.

There is only one man on our approved list capable of doing this work. That is Mr. Albert Leneville. He would want 80 cents per hour and we would have to pay for his time while travelling and also his travelling expenses to and from Guy School. I recommend that the men at the School be employed. I cannot recall the name of this man.

I would like to know your decision in this matter as soon as possible. Nothing will be done until I hear from you.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sirs:

On April 16th, I visited your Mission School at Sturgeon Landing, as per your request of earlier date, for the purpose of checking over the Singer Sewing Machines in use there.

Enclosed please find my report.

Owing to the materials used, and the amount of sewing done, I would suggest that the Oscillating or round shuttle machine be used for replacement. The machines of this type, in use at the present time, have been very satisfactory and given excellent service. They are much more practical than the long or Vibrating shuttle machines.

Upon inspection of the machines in question, I found them to be very clean, well oiled, and generally in a condition that would suggest the best of care.

Looking forward to being of further service to you in this matter, I remain,

Yours very truly,

Head Office, Flin Flon, Manitoba.
Dear Sir:

Jan 19, 1943

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

In answer to your letter, file No. 132-7-5, dated January 5.

I would like to draw your attention to the fact that in 1941, permission was given to buy a water-tank and have the same erected at the Guy Industrial School. The taking down of the old tank and the erection to be under the direction of the Principal Rev. Father Doyon, for the sum of $150.00.

Owing to transportation difficulties, low water in the lake and wet road, which made it impossible to transport lumber for the tank in until after freeze up, it was therefore too late to erect the tank that year.

In the summer of 1942 I met Ismael Gauthier and the erection of the tank was mentioned as this man was hired by the Father to do the work in 1941.

At the end of July I was informed that the construction of the tank was underway and intended to notify the department to that effect, owing to the rush at Treaty and other work it slipped my mind. I heard nothing further until I received the account for same; this account has been held until I had the opportunity of going into the school and inspecting the tank. At present there is approximately 10 to 11 feet of water in the tank. The tank will gradually swell and the capacity will increase as the lumber tightens up.
I would like to draw your attention to the fact that this work was absolutely a necessity as the old tank was rotten and did not hold at any time more than 3 feet of water, which would be useless in the event of fire.

While the account as rendered is more than the authority granted in 1941, the price on the whole is very fair in fact 60 cents an hour for that class of work is cheap, and the time taken is very considerate.

I am very sorry that permission was not granted before this work proceeded and will take extra precautions to see that this does not happen again. I strongly recommend that this account be paid.

Samuel Lovell
S. Lovell,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am directed by His Excellency Bishop Lajeunesse to inform you of the difficulty the Guy Indian Residential School has regarding transportation of its freight during the summer time.

The only good and practical way of transportation during the summer is a water route, on the Goose Lake, from Education or Mile 39 on the C.N.Railroad to Sturgeon Landing. They did not use that route for the last three years on account of low water level. But as the water level is rather high this summer and seems to be remaining so for four months they would like to profit again with that route but the difficulty is to have their freight unloaded at the right place by the C.N.R.

The right place would be Education or Mile 39 on the Pas--Flin Flon C.N.R. Subdivision. The C.N.R. Co. allows the Passenger Train No 63--64 to stop there but not the mixed train No 529-530. There is no road at all between Education and the nearest station where the train stops, namely Simonhouse. Unless the mixed train is allowed to stop at Education they cannot at all have their freight in from the C.N.R. Railroad up to Sturgeon Landing.

His Excellency has suggested me to come in touch with you and ask you if you would be kind enough to take the matter with the superintendant of the C.N.R. Mr. F.J. Myer, in order to have the mixed train No 529-530 stopping at Education during the months of July, August, Sept. and Oct. Mr. F.J. Myer's address is: Mr. F.J. Myer, Superintendant of Flin Flon Subdivision, Dauphin, Manitoba.

Thanking you in advance for your cooperation we remain,

Yours very truly,

E. Ringust, Bursar.

Ottawa, July 6, 1943.

Dear Sir:

I am advised that the most practical way of transporting supplies to the Guy Indian Residential School is a water route on the Goose Lake, from Education or Mile 39 on the C. N. Railroad to Sturgeon Landing.

As you are no doubt aware, this school is the property of the Dominion Government and is operated for us by the Catholic Church in educating Indian children of that district.

I am further advised that the Canadian National Railway allows passenger train No. 65-64 to stop at Education but does not allow the mixed train No. 529-230 to stop there. It would assist the management of our Guy Residential School to a very great extent if it could be arranged to have the mixed train stop at Education during the months of July, August, September and October, 1943. This would permit the unloading of the goods consigned to the school at Education and their transportation from that point to the school, by water, as mentioned in the first paragraph of this letter.

The Department trusts that you will find it possible to meet our wishes in this particular respect.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

We take great pleasure in extending to you our sincere thanks for your intervention regarding additional train stops at education.

However we regret to say that it is entirely impossible to have our freight unloaded at either Mileage 41.0 or Mileage 42.2 because there is no land road of any kind along the way of transportation between Education and Mileage 41.0. On the other hand the freighters for our school cannot reach Simon House or Mileage #2.2 by water road.

Therefore to accept Mr. Myers' suggestion would mean to carry on their shoulders, from mile 41.0 to mile 39.0, the heavy bags or cases or whatever it might be. You agree with us that it cannot be done that way.

We are wondering if it could not be possible to have the freight unloaded at Simonhouse and have the section-man taking it to destination, mile 39, by gaz-car. We think that's the only way the situation can be help.

As you see the transportation of our school supply in summer is quite a problem chiefly today when the suppliers cannot guarantee delivery of goods for the time we ask for, that is rather in wintertime.

Hoping that something will be done to better the situation, we remain

Yours very truly,

The Principal of Guy Indian Residential School has pointed out to me that their steam boiler has never been inspected by the boiler inspector since it was installed. No doubt this is due to the fact that the school is in unorganized territory.

It was brought to my attention when I last visited Guy Indian Residential School that the following repairs were urgently required.

Repair for Kitchen Range.

The top of the range is dropping badly owing to a brace inside the top being broken. The Range is a Gurney Oxford, made by the Gurney Foundry Co. The number on the stove is No. 2030 F. Name on oven door "John Bull". The brace has no number but it is underneath the stove top next to the firebox to the right as one faces the stove. I believe the address of the Gurney Foundry Co. is Toronto, though there is nothing on the stove to indicate this. We would like this to be ordered and sent to the Guy Indian Residential School, Atik, Man.

Childrens' Dining Room Tables

There are four tables in the Childrens' dining room. They are homemade and were formerly covered with battleship Linoleum. The linoleum has been worn out and there is none left, consequently it is impossible to keep the tables clean and sanitary as the food gets in between the boards of the table and it is impossible to get it out. They want the tables re-covered with battleship linoleum. That is 10 square yards of Linoleum. The cost of this at The Pas is about $3.00 per sq. yard. If battleship linoleum could not be procured, a heavy linoleum other than battleship would suffice.

S. Lovell,
Indian Agent.
